Unjustifiably ascribed to Marlowe. Possibly identical with "The Spanish Moor's tragedy," by Dekker, Haughton and Day. Cf. Cambridge hist. of Eng. lit. ; DNB.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Lusts Dominion; OR, THE Lascivious Queen. A TRAGEDIE.
LONDON, Printed for F. K. and are to be sold by Robert Pollard, at the sign of Ben. Johnsons head, on the back-side of the Old-Exchange. 1657.

list.item: Eleazar the Moor, Prince of Fesse and Barbary.
Philip King of Spain, Father to Fernando, Philip, and Isabella.
Fernando King of Spain Philip Prince of Spain Sons to Philip.
Alvero a Nobleman, and Father in Law to Eleazar, and Father to Hortenzo and Maria.
Christofero Roderigo two Noblemen of Spain.
Hortenzo Lover to Isabella, and son to Alvero.
Zarack, Baltazar two Moors, attending Eleazar.
The Queen Mother of Spain, and wife K. Philip.
Maria wife to Eleazar, and daughter Alvero.

div.p: Lusts Dominion. OR, The Lascivious Queen. A TRAGEDY.
LONDON: Printed for Fr. Kirkman at the John Fletchers Head over against the Angel-Inn on the backside of St. Clements without Temple-Barre, 1661.

div.head: To my worthily honored Friend William Carpenter, Esquire.
div.p:
MY Ambition hath long soared so high, as to prompt me to somewhat whereby I might in part render to you my gratitude: and not yet finding any service I can act for you, a sufficient or competent return of any part of those many favours you have still honored me withall; I took on me the resolution
(rather than to be thought wholly negligent of you) to lay hold on this means of rendring you my service. SIR! This Piece, which without your favour and command had never past the Presse, I here present to you with this confidence, that as you were instrumental in its production to the world, so your name and favour will be sufficient to protect it from the calumny of this censorious age In doing of which you will multiply those obligations you have conferred upon

closer.signed: Your devoted Servant FRA. KIRKMAN. June

div.head: Lusts Dominion; OR, THE Lascivious Queen.
A TRAGEDIE.
Act. Imus.
Scena Ima.
div.stage: Enter Zaracke, Baltazar, two Moors taking tobacco musick sounding within: enter Queen Mother of Spain with two pages, Eleanor sitting on a chair suddenly draws the curtain.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: ON me, does music spend this sound on me
That hate all unity: ha: Zarack Baltazar?

sp.speaker: Que. Mo.
sp.l: My gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Are you there with your Beagles? hark you slaves,
Did not I bind you on your lives, to watch that none disturbed us.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Gentle Eleazar.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: There, off: Is it you that deaf me with this noise?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Why is my loves aspect so grim and horrid?
Look smoothly on me:
Chime out your softest strains of harmony,
And on delicious Musics silken wings
Send ravishing delight to my loves ears,
That he may be enamoured of your tunes.
Come let us kiss.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: No, no, says I; and twice away says stay:
Come, come, I will have a kiss, but if you strive
For one denial you shall forfeit five.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Nay prithee good Queen leave me,
I am now sick, heavy, and dull as lead.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I will make thee lighter by taking something from thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Do: take from me this Ague and these fits that hanging on me
Shake me in pieces, and set all my blood
A-boiling with the fire of rage: away, away
Thou believest I jest: and laughest, to see my wrath wear antic shapes:
Be gone, be gone.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: What means my love, burst all those wires? burn all those Instruments?
For they displease my Moor. Art thou now pleased,
Or wert thou now disturbed? I will wage all Spain
To one sweet kiss, this is some new device
To make me fond and long. O! you men
Have tricks to make poor women die for you.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: What die for me; away.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Away, what way? I prithee speak more kindly;
Why dost thou frown? at whom?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: At thee.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: At me? O why at me? for each contracted frown
A crooked wrinkle interlines my brow:
Spend but one hour in frowns, and I shall look
Like to a Beldam of one hundred years:
I prithee speak to me and chide me not,
I prithee chide if I have done amiss,
But let my punishment be this, and this.
I prithee smile on me, if but a while,
Then frown on me, I will die: I prithee smile:
Smile on me, and these two wanton boys,
these pretty lads that do attend on me,
Shall call thee Jove, shall wait upon thy cup
And fill thee Nectar: their enticing eyes
Shall serve as crystal, wherein thou mayst see
To dress thyself, if thou wilt smile on me.
Smile on me, and with coroners of pearl,
And bells of gold, circling their pretty arms
In a round Ivory fount these two shall swim,
And dive to make thee sport:
Bestow one smile, one little little smile,
And in a net of twisted silk and gold
In my all-naked arms, thyself shalt lie.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Why, what to do? Lusts arms do stretch so wide.
That none can fill them? I will lay there away.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Where hast thou learned this language? that can say
No more but two rude words; away, away:
Am I grown ugly now?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ugly as hell.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thou lovedest me once.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: That can thy bastards tell.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What is my sin? I will amend the same.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hence strumpet, use of sin makes thee past shame.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Eliaz.
sp.l: I Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Too true It is, woe is me;
I am a Strumpet, but made so by thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: By me; no, no; by these young bawds; fetch thee a glass
And thou shalt see the balls of both thine eyes
Burning in fire of lust; by me? there is here
Within this hollow cistern of thy breast
A spring of hot blood: have not I to cool it
Made an extraction to the quintessence
Even of my soul: melted all my spirits,
Ravished my youth, deflowered my lovely cheeks.
And dried this, this to anatomy
Only to feed your lust, (these boys have ears):
Yet wouldst thou murther me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I murder thee?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I cannot ride through the Castilian streets
But thousand eyes through windows, and through doors
Throw killing looks at me, and every slave
At Eleazar darts a finger out,
And every hissing tongue cries, There is the Moor,
That is he that makes a Cuckold of our King,
there goes the Minion of the Spanish Queen;
That is the black Prince of Devils, there goes he
That on smooth boys, on Masks and Revellings
Spends the Revenues of the King of Spain.
Who arms this many headed beast but you,
Murder and Lust are twins, and both are thine;
Being weary of me thou wouldst worry me,
Because some new love makes thee loath thine old.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Eleazar!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Harlot! I will not hear thee speak.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: I will kill myself unless thou hearest me speak.
My husband King upon his death-bed lies,
Yet have I stolen from him to look on thee;
A Queen hath made herself thy Concubine:
Yet dost thou now abhor me, hear me speak!
Else shall my sons plague thy adulterous wrongs,
And tread upon thy heart for murdering me,
Thy tongue hath murdered me (Cry murder boys)

sp.speaker: 2 Boies
sp.l: Murder! the Queen is murdered!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Love? slaves peace?

sp.speaker: 2 Boies
sp.l: Murder! the Queen is murdered!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Stop your throats?
Hark Hush you Squalls; Dear love look up:
Our Chamber window stares into the Court,
And every wide mouthed ear, hearing this news
Will give Alarum to the cuckold King.
I did dissemble when I chid my love,
And that dissembling was to try my love

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Thou calledst me strumpet.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I will tear out my tongue

From this black temple for blaspheming
thee.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: And when I wooed thee but to smile on me,
Thou criedest, away, away, and frownedest upon me.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Come now I will kiss thee, now I will smile upon thee;
Call to thy ashy cheeks their wonted red:
Come frown not, pout not, smile, smile, but upon me
And with my poniard will I stab my flesh,
And quaff carouses to thee of my blood,
Whilst in moist Nectar kisses thou dost pledge me.
How now, why starest thou thus?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: The King is dead.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha! dead! you hear this, is it true, is it true, the King dead!
Who dare knock thus?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: It is the Cardinal, making inquiry if the Queen were here.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: See? she is here, tell him? and yet Zarack stay.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: Don Rdoerigo is come to seek the Queen.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Why should Roderigo seek her here?

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: The King hath swooned thrice, and being recovered,
Sends up and down the Court, to seek her grace.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: The King was dead with you; Run? and with a voice.
Erected high as mine, say thus, thus threaten
To Roderigo and the Cardinal.
Seek no Queens here, I will broach them if they do,
Upon my falchions point. Again more knocking!

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Your father is at hand, my Gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Lock all the chambers, bar him out you apes.
Hither, a vengeance; stir Eugenia,
You know your old walk under ground, away.
So down hie to the King, quick, quick, you Squalls
Crawl with your Dam, in the dark, dear love farewell,
One day I hope to shut you up in hell.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: SOn Eleazar, saw you not the Queen?

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: Was not the Queen here with you?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Queen with me; because my Lord I am married to your daughter:
You (like your daughter) will grow Jealous,
The Queen with me, with me, a Moore, a Devil,
A slave of Barbary, a dog; for so
Your silken Courtiers christen me, but father
Although my flesh be tawny, in my veins,
Runs blood as red, and royal as the best
And proudest in Spain, there does old man: my father,
Who with his Empire, lost his life,
And left me Captive to a Spanish Tyrant, O!
Go tell him! Spanish Tyrant? tell him, do?
He that can lose a kingdom and not rave,
He is a tame jade, I am not, tell old Philip
I call him Tyrant here is a sword and arms,
A heart, a head, and so pish, It is but death:
Old fellow she is not here. But ere I die,
Sword I will bequeath thee a rich legacy.

sp.speaker: Alvero
sp.l: Watch fitter hours to think on wrongs than now,
Deaths frozen hand holds Royal Philip's heart,
Half of his body lies within a grave;
Then do not now by quarrels shake that state,
Which is already too much ruinate.
Come and take leave of him before he die.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I will follow you, now purple villainy;
Sit like a Robe imperial on my back,
That under thee I closelier may contrive
My vengeance; foul deeds hid do sweetly thrive:
Mischief erect thy throne and sit in state
Here, here upon this head; let fools fear fate.
Thus I defy my stars, I care not I
How low I tumble down, so I mount high.
Old time I will wait bare-headed at thy heels,
and be a foot-boy to thy winged hours;
They shall not tell one Minute out in sands,
But I will set down the number, I will still wake,
And waste these balls of sight by tossing them;
In busy observations upon thee.
Sweet opportunity I will bind myself
to thee in base apprentice-hood so long,
Till on thy naked scalp grow hair as thick
As mine: and all hands shall lay hold on thee,
If thou wilt lend me but thy rusty scythe,
To cut down all that stand within my wrongs,
And my revenge. Love dance in twenty forms
Upon my beauty, that this Spanish dame
May be bewitched, and dote, her amorous flames
Shall blow up the old King. Consume his Sons,
And make all Spain a bonfire.
This Tragedy being acted hers does begin,
To shed a harlots blood can be no sin.

div.head: Act. Imus. Scena 3tia.
div.stage: The Courtains being drawn there appears in his bed King Phillip, with his Lords, the Princesse Isabella, at the feet Mendoza, Alvero, Hortensio, Fernando, Roderigo, and to them Enter Queen in hast.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: WHose was that Screech-Owls voice, that like the sound
Of a hell tortured soul rung through mine ears
Nothing but horrid shrieks, nothing but death?
Whilst I, veiling my knees to the cold earth,
Drowning my withered cheeks in my warm tears,
And stretching out my arms to pull from heaven
Health for the Royal Majesty of Spain,
All cried, The Majesty of Spain is dead:
That last word [dead] struck through the echoing air,
Rebounded on my heart, and smote me down
Breathless to the cold earth, and made me leave
My prayers for Philips life, but thanks to heaven
I see him live, and lives I hope to see
Unnumbered years to guide this Empery.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: The number of my years ends in one day,
Ere this Sun is down all a King's glory sets,
For all our lives are but deaths counterfeits.
Father Mendoza and you Peers of Spain,
Dry your wet eyes, for sorrow wanteth force
To inspire a breathing soul in a dead coarse;
Such is your King: Where is Isabel our Daughter?

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: At your beds-seat confounded in her tears.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: She of your grief the heaviest burthen bears;
You can but lose a King, but she a Father.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: She bear the heaviest burthen; O say rather
I bear, and am born down, my sorrowing
Is for a husbands loss, loss of a King.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: No more, Alvere call the Princess hither.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: Madam, his Majesty doth call for you.

sp.speaker: K. Ph.
sp.l: Come hither Isabella, reach a hand;
Yet now it shall not need, in stead of thine
Death shoving thee back clasp his hands in mine,
And bids me come away, I must, I must;
Though Kings be gods on earth, they turn to dust.
Is not Prince Philip come from Portugal?

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: The Prince as yet is not returned, my Lord.

sp.speaker: K. Ph.
sp.l: Commend me to him, if I never behold him:
This tells the order of my funeral,
Do it as It is set down? Embalm my body;
Though worms do make no difference of flesh;
Yet Kings are curious here to dig their graves,
Such is man's frailty; when I am embalmed,
Apparel me in a rich Royal Robe,
According to the custom of the Land;
Then place my bones within that brazen shrine
Which death hath builded for my ancestors:
I cannot name death, but he strait steps in,
And pulls me by the arm.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: His Grace doth faint: help me my Lords softly to raise him up.

div.stage: Enter Eleazar, and stands sadly by.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Lift me not up, I shortly must go down,
When a few dribbling minutes have run out;
Mine hour is ended: King of Spain farewell:
You all acknowledge him your Sovereign.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: When you are dead we will acknowledge him.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Govern this kingdom well: to be a King
Is given to many: but to govern well
Granted to few: have care to Isabel,
Her virtue was King Philips looking-glass.
Reverence the Queen your mother. Love your sister,
And the young Prince your brother; even that day
When Spain shall solemnise my Obsequies,
And lay me up in earth; let them crown you.
Where is Eleazar, Don Alvero's son?

sp.speaker: Fernand.
sp.l: Yonder with crossed arms stands he malcontent.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: I do commend him to thee for a man
Both wise and warlike, yet beware of him,
Ambition wings his spirit, keep him down;
What will not men attempt to win a crown.
Mendoza is Protector of thy Realm,
I did elect him for his gravity,
I trust he will be a father to thy youth:
Call help Fernando, now I faint indeed.

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: My Lords.

sp.speaker: K. Phil.
sp.l: Let none with a distracted voice
Shriek out, and trouble me in my departure:
Heavens hands I see are beckoning for my soul;
I come, I come; thus do the proudest die,
Death hath no mercy, life no certainty.

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: As yet his soul is not from her temple gone.
Therefore forbear loud lamentation.

sp.speaker: Queen. Mo.
sp.l: O he is dead, he is dead! lament and die,
In her King's end begins Spain's misery

sp.speaker: Isa
sp.l: He shall not end so soon; Father, dear Father!

sp.speaker: Fern.
sp.l: Forbear sweet Isabella, shrieks are vain.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You cry forbear, you by his loss of breath
Have won a kingdom, you may cry forbear:
But I have lost a Father, and a King;
And no tongue shall control my sorrowing.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: Whither, good Isabella?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I will go,
Where I will languish in eternal woe.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: Nay, gentle Love.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Talk not of love to me.
The world and the Worlds pride henceforth I will scorn.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: My love shall follow thee, if thou deniest
To live with poor Hortenzo as his wife;
I will never change my love, but change my life.

sp.speaker: Phillip.
sp.l: I know he is not dead, I know proud Death
Durst not behold such sacred majesty.
Why stand you thus distracted? Mother, Brother,
My Lord Mendoza, where is my Royal father?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Here lies the temple of his Royal soul.

sp.speaker: Fernan.
sp.l: Here is all that is left of Philips Majesty.
Wash you his tomb with tears; Fernandoes moan,
Hating a Partner, shall be spent alone.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O happy father, miserable Son!
Philip is gone to Joy Philip is forlorn:
He dies to live; my life with woe is torn.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Sweet son.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sweet mother: o! how I now do shame
To lay on one so foul so fair a name:
Had you been a true mother, a true wife,
This King had not so soon been robbed of life.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What means this rage, my son?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Call not me your son:
My father whilst he lived tired his strong arms
In bearing christian armour, against the Turk's
And spent his brains in warlike stratagems
To bring Confusion on damned Infidels;
Whilst you that snorted here at home betrayed
His name to everlasting Infamy;
Whilst you at home suffered his bed-chamber
To be a Brothelry, whilst you at home
Suffered his Queen to be a Concubine;
And wanton red cheeked boys to be her bawds
Whilst she reeking in that lechers arms.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Me!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Villain It is thee, thou hell-begotten fiend at thee I stare.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Philip thou art a villain to dishonour me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mother I am no villain; It is this villain
Dishonours you and me, dishonours Spain,
Dishonours all these Lords, this Devil is he, that --

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: What! O pardon me I must throw off
All chains of duty: wert thou ten Kings sons,
Had I as many souls as I have sins:
As this from hence, so they from this should fly;
In just revenge of this Indignity.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Give way, or I will make way upon your bosoms.

sp.speaker: Eleazer.
sp.l: Did my dear Sovereign live, sirrah that tongue.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Did but King Philip live, traitor I would tell, --

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A tale, that should rid both your souls to hell.
Tell Philip's ghost, that Philip tells his Queen,
That Philip's Queen is a Moor's Concubine:
Did the King live I would tell him how you two,
Ripped up the entrails of his treasury:
With Masques and antic Revellings.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Words insupportable; dost hear me boy?

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Stand you all still, and see me thus trod down.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Stand you all still, yet let this devil stand here.

sp.speaker: Mendo
sp.l: Forbear sweet Prince; Eleazar, I am now
Protector to Fernando King of Spain:
By that authority and by consent
Of all these peers, I utterly deprive thee
Of all those Royalties thou holdest in Spain,

sp.speaker: Qu. M.
sp.l: Cardinal, who lends thee this Commission?

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Cardinal, I will shorten thee by thy head for this.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Forward my Lord Mendoza, damn the fiend:

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Princes of Spain, consent you to this pride?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: we do.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: For what cause? let his faith be tried

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: His treasons needs no trial, they are too plain;
Come not within the Court, for if you do,
To beg with Indian slaves I will banish you.

div.stage: Exeunt all, but Alvero, Queen, and Eleazar

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: WHy should my son be banished?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Of that dispute not now Alvero,
I will to the King my son, it shall be tried
If Castiles King can cool a Cardinal's pride.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: If I digest this Gall; O! my Maria:
I am whipped, and racked, and torn upon the wheel
Of giddy fortune: She and her Minions
Have got me down; and treading on my bosom.
They cry, lie still: the Cardinal
(O! rare) would bandy me away from Spain,
And banish me to beg; I, beg with slaves.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Conquer with patience these indignities.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Patience; ha, ha: yes, yes: an honest Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yet smother the grief and seek revenge.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha! banish me, 'sfoot, why say hey do;
There is Portugal a good air, and France a fine Country;
Or Barbary rich, and has Moors; the Turke
Pure Devil, and allows enough to fat
The sides of villainy; good living there:
I can live there, and there, and there,
Troth It is, a villain can live anywhere:
But say I go from hence, I leave behind me
A Cardinal, that will laugh, I leave behind me
A Philip, that will clap his hands for joy;
And dance lavoltas through the Castile Court.
But the deepest wound of all is this, I leave
My wrongs, dishonours, and my discontents,
O! unrevenged; my bed-rid enemies
Shall never be raised up by the strong Physical,
Curing of my sword, therefore stay still;
Many have hearts to strike, that dare not kill
Leave me Maria: Cardinal, this disgrace,
Shall dye thy soul, as Inky as my face:
Pish, hence Maria.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: To the King I will fly.
He shall revenge my Lord's indignity.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: Mendoza woos the King to banish thee;
Startle thy wonted spirits, awake thy soul
And on thy resolution fasten wings,
Whose golden feathers may out-strip their hate,

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I will tie no golden feathers to my wings.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: Shall they thus tread thee down which once were glad,
To Lackey by thy conquering Chariot wheels.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I care not, I can swallow more sour wrongs:

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: If they triumph over thee; they spurn me down.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Look, spurn again.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: what Ice hath cooled that fire,
Which sometimes made thy thoughts heaven aspire;
This patience had not wont to dwell with thee:

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: It is right, but now the World is changed you see;
Though I seem dead to you, here lives a fire,
No more, here comes the King, and my Maria;
The Spaniard loves my wife, she swears to me,
She is chaste as the white Moon, well if she be.
Well too if she be not, I care not, I,
I will climb up by that love to dignity.

sp.speaker: Fernan.
sp.l: Thou wooest me to revenge thy husbands wrong,
I woo thy fair self not to wrong thyself;
Swear but to love me, and to thee I will swear
To crown thy husband with a diadem.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Such love as I dare yield, I will not deny.

sp.speaker: Fernan.
sp.l: When in the golden arms of Majesty.
I am broke off; yonder thy husband stands,
I will set him free, if thou unite my bands,
So much for that. Durst then the Cardinal,
Put on such insolence; tell me fair Madam,
Where is your most Valiant Husband?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: He sees me, and yet enquires for me.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Yonder is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fernan.
sp.l: Eleazar I have in my breast writ down
From her Report your late received disgrace:
My father loved you dearly, so will I.

sp.speaker: Eliaz.
sp.l: True, for my wife's sake.

sp.speaker: Fernan.
sp.l: This Indignity will I have Interest in for being your King,
You shall perceive I will curb my underling:
This morning is our Coronation
And father's funeral solemnised,
Be present, step into your wonted place;
We will guild your dim disgraces with our grace.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I thank my Sovereign that you love my wife;
I thank thee wife that thou wilt lock my head
In such strong armour, to bear off all blows;
Who dare say such wives are their husband foes:
Let us see now, by her falling I must rise.
Cardinal you die, if the King bid me live;
Philip you die for railing at me: proud Lord you die,
That with Mendoza cried, Banish the Moor.
And you my loving Liege, you are best sit fast
If all these live not, you must die at last.

div.trailer: The end of the first Act.

div.head: Act. II. Scena. I.
div.stage: Enter two Lords, Philip his brother, Mendoza, Eleazar with him, the King Crown'd, Queen mother, Alvero, Zarack, Baltazar, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: WHy stares this Devil thus, as if pale death
Had made his eyes the dreadful messengers
To carry black destruction to the world.
Was he not banished Spain?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your sacred mouth, pronounced the sentence of his banishment:
Then spurn the villain forth.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Who spurns the Moor, were better set his foot upon the Devil,
Do; spurn me? and this confounding arm of wrath
Shall like a thunderbolt breaking the clouds
Divide his body from his soul. Stand back.
Spurn Eleazar?

sp.speaker: Rode.
sp.l: Shall we bear his pride.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: Why not, he under went much Injury,

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: What injury have we performed proud Lord?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Proud Cardinal; my unjust banishment.

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: It was we that did it; and our words are laws.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: It was we repealed him, and our words are laws.

sp.speaker: Zara. Baltaz.
sp.l: If not these are.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How! threatened and out-dared?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Shall we give arm to hostile violence?
Sheath your swords, sheath them, it is we command.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Grant Eleaz. justice my dread Liege

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: Eleazar hath had justice from our hands,
And he stands banished from the Court of Spain,

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Have you done justice? why Lord Cardinal,
From whom do you derive authority,
To banish him the Court without our leave?

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: From this, the Staff of our Protectorship;
From this, which the last will of your dead Father
Committed to our trust: from this high place
Which lifts Mendoza's spirits beyond the pitch
Of ordinary honour, and from this.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Which too much overweening Insolence Hath quite taken from you, Eleazar up,

div.stage: takes the staff from Mendoza and gives it to Eleaz.

sp.l: And from us sway this Staff of Regency.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dare sons presume to break their fathers will?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Dare Subjects counter-check their Sovereigns will?
It is done, and who gainsays it is a Traitor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I do Fernando, yet I am no Traitor.

sp.speaker: Mendo.
sp.l: Fernando I am wronged by Peters Chair,
Mendoza vows revenge. I will lay aside
My Cardinals hat, and in a wall of steel
The glorious livery of a soldier; fight for my late lost honour

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: King, thou shalt be no King for wronging me.
The Pope shall send his bulls through all thy Realm,
And pull obedience from thy Subjects hearts,
To put on armour of the Mother Church,
Curses shall fall like lightnings on your heads:
Bell, book and candle, holy water, prayers,
Shall all chime vengeance to the of Court Spain
Till they have power to conjure down that fiend;
That damned Moor, that Devil, that Lucifer,
That dares aspire the staff, the Cardinal swayed.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha ha ha, I laugh yet, that the Cardinal is vexed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Laughest thou base slave, the wrinkles of that scorn
Thine own heart blood shall fill; Brother farewell,
Since you disprove the will our father left,
For base lust of a loathed Concubine.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha, Concubine; who does Prince Philip mean?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thy wife, thy daughter, base aspiring Lords,
Who to buy honour, are content to sell,
Your names to infamy, your souls to hell:
And stamp you now? do, do, for you shall see,
I go for vengeance, and she will come with me.

sp.speaker: Eliaz.
sp.l: Stay, for she is here already, see proud boy.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: Hold, stay this fury, if you long for blood,
Murder me first. Dear son you are a King:
Then stay the violent tempest of their wrath.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Shall Kings be overswayed in their desires?

sp.speaker: Roderi.
sp.l: Shall Subjects be oppressed by tyranny?

sp.speaker: Q. Mother.
sp.l: No State shall suffer wrong, then hear me speak,
Mendo, you have sworn you love the Queen,
Then by that love I charge you leave these arms:
Eliaz. for those favours I have given you,
Embrace the Cardinal, and be friends with him.

sp.speaker: Eliaz.
sp.l: And have my wife called strumpet to my face.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: It was rage made his tongue err, do you not know
The violent love Mendoza bears the Queen:
Then speak him fair, for in that honeyed breath
I will lay a bait shall train him to his death.
Come, come, I see your looks give way to peace;
Lord Cardinal begin, and for reward,
Ere this fair setting Sun behold his bride;
Be bold to challenge love, yet be denied

sp.speaker: Mendoz.
sp.l: That promise makes me yield; my gracious Lord:
Although my disgrace hath graven its memory
On every Spaniards eye, yet shall the duty
I owe your sacred Highness; and the love
My Country challengeth, make me lay by
Hostile intendments, and return again
To the fair circle of obedience.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Both pardon and our favour bids you welcome,
And for some satisfaction for your wrongs,
We here create you Salamanka's Duke,
But first as a true sign all grudges die;
Shake hands with Eleazar and be friends;
This union pleaseth us, now brother Philip,
You are included in this league of love,
So is Roderigo to forget all wrongs:
Your Castle for a while shall bid us welcome,
Eleazar shall it not? It is enough,
Lords lead the way, that whilst you feast yourselves,
Fernando may find time all means to prove,
To compass fair Maria for our love.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: MAdam a word now, have you wit or spirit?

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: Both.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Set them both to a most gainful task,
Our enemies are in my Castle-work.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: I; but the King is there too, it is dangerous pride,
To strike at those; that couch by a Lion's side.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Remove them:

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: How? a thousand ways;
By poison, or by this, but every groom
Has skill in such base traffic; no our policies
Must look more strange, must fly with loftier wings:
Vengeance the higher it falls, more horror brings:
But you are cold, you dare not do.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: I dare.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: You have a woman's heart, look you this hand,
O! It is too little to strike home.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: At whom?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Your son.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother.
sp.l: Which son, the King?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Angels of heaven, stand like his guard about him, how? the King
Not for so many worlds as here be stars,
Sticking upon the embroidered firmament.
The King? he loves my wife and should he die;
I know none else would love her, let him live.
(in heaven) good Lord Philip.

sp.speaker: Queen Mother
sp.l: He shall die.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: How? good good.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: By this hand.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: When, good good; when?

sp.speaker: Qu. M.
sp.l: This night if Eleazer give consent;

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Why then this night Philip shall not live,
To see you kill him. Is he not your son?
A mother be the murderer of a brat,
That lived within her; ha!

sp.speaker: Qu. Mother
sp.l: It is for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Puh! What excuses cannot damned sin make
To save itself, I know you love him well,
But that he has an eye, an eye, an eye,
To others our two hearts seem to be locked
Up in a case of steel, upon our love others
Dare not look, or if they dare, they cast
Squint purblind glances; who care though all see all,
So long as none dare speak, but, Philip
Knows that the Iron ribs of our villains
Are thin: He laughs to see them like this hand,
With chinks, and crevices, how a villainous eye,
A stabbing desperate tongue, the boy dare speak,
A mouth, a villainous mouth, let us muzzle him.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Thus.
Go you, and with a face well set do
In good sad colours; such as paint out
The cheek of that fool penitence, and with a tongue
Made clean and glib, Cull from their lazy swarm;
Some honest Friars, whom that damnation gold,
Can tempt to lay their souls to the stake;
Seek such, they are rank and thick.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: What then, I know such, what is the use?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: This is excellent.
Hire these to write books, preach and proclaim abroad,
That your son Philip is a bastard.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A bastard; do you; know a bastard? do it;
Say conscience spake with you, and cried out, do it
By this means shall you thrust him from all hopes
Of wearing Castiles diadem, and that spur
Galling his sides, he will fly out, and fling,
And grind the Cardinals heart to a new edge
Of discontent, from discontent grows treason,
And on the stalk of treason death: he is dead
By this blow, and by you; yet no blood shed.
Do it then; by this trick, he gon!
We stand more sure in climbing high;
Care not who fall It is real policy:
Are you armed to do this? ha!

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: Sweet Moor it is done.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Away then, work with boldness, and with speed;
On greatest actions greatest dangers feed.
Ha, ha, I thank thee provident creation,
That seeing in moulding me thou didst intend,
I should prove villain, thanks to thee and nature
That skilful workman; thanks for my face,
Thanks that I have not wit to blush.
What Zarack? ho Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: my Lord.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Nearer, so silence;
Hang both your greedy ears upon my lips,
Let them devour my speech, suck in my breath;
And in who lets it break prison, here is his death,
This night the Cardinal shall be murdered.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: And to fill up a grave Philip dies:

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: By thee; and slave by thee:
Have you hearts and hands to execute?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Here is both.

sp.speaker: 1 Moor.
sp.l: He dies were he my father.

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Ho away?
Stay, go, go, stay, see me no more till night;
Your cheeks are black, let not your souls look white:

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Till night.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Till night, a word, the Mother Queen
Is trying if she can with fire of gold,
Warp the green consciences of two covetous Friars,
To preach abroad Philip's bastardy.

sp.speaker: 1 Moor.
sp.l: His bastardy, who was his father?

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: Who?
Search for these friars, hire them to work with you;
Their holy callings will approve the fact.
Most good and meritorious; sin shines clear,
When her black face Religions masque doth wear.
Here comes the Queen, good; and the Friars.

div.head: Act. II. Scena. III.
div.stage: Enter two Friers, Crab and Cole; and Queen Mother.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: YOur son a bastard; say we do,
But how then shall we deal with you?
I tell you as I said before;
His being a bastard, you are so poor
In honour and in name, that time
Can never take away the crime.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: I grant that Friar, yet rather I will endure
The wound of infamy, to kill my name,
Than to see Spain bleeding, with civil swords
The boy is proud, ambitious, he woos greatness,
He takes up Spanish hearts on trust, to pay them
When he shall finger Castiles Crown: O then
Were it not better my disgrace were known,
Than such a base aspirer fill the Throne.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Ha brother Crab, what think you?

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: As you dear brother Cole:

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Then we agree,
Coles Judgment is as Crabs you see.
Lady we swear to speak and write,
What you please so all go right.

sp.speaker: Queen. Mo.
sp.l: Then as we gave directions, spread abroad,
In Cales, Madrid, Granado, and Medyna;
And all the Royal Cities of the Realm:
The ambitious hopes of that proud bastard Philip,
And sometimes as you see occasion,
Tickle the ears of the Rude multitude,
With Eleazars praises; guild his virtues,
Naples recovery and his victories
Achieved against the Tutkish Ottoman:
Will you do this for us?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Say will you?

sp.speaker: Both
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Why start you back and stare? ha? are you afraid.

sp.speaker: Cole
sp.l: O? no Sir, no, but truth to tell;
Seeing your face, we thought of hell.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hell is a dream.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: But none do dream in hell.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Friars stand to her; and me; and by your sin,
I will shoulder out Mendoza from his seat;
And of two Friars create you Cardinals,
O! how would Cardinal's hats on these heads sit.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: This face would look most goodly under it:
Friar, Crab and Cole do swear,
In those circles still to appear:
In which she, or you, do charge us rise;
For you, our lives we will sacrifice.
Valete, Gaudete;
Cole will be burnt, and Crab be pressed;
Ere they prove knaves, thus are you crossed and blessed.

sp.speaker: Eleaz,
sp.l: Away; you know now Madam none shall throw
Their leaden envy in an opposite scale,
To weigh down our true golden happiness.

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: Yes, there is one.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: One, who? give me his name and I will
Turn it to a magic spell,
To bind him here, here, who?

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: Your wife Maria.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha! my Maria.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: She is the Hellespont divides my love and me,
She being cut off.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Stay, stay, cut off; let us think upon it, my wife?
Humh! Kill her too!

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Does her love make thee cold?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Had I a thousand wives, down go they all:
She dies, I will cut her off: now Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: Madam, the King entreats your company.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: His pleasure be obeyed, dear love farewell;
Remember your Maria.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Here adieu;
With this I will guard her, whilst it stabs at you.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: My Lord! the Friars are won to join with us.

sp.speaker: Eliaz.
sp.l: Be prosperous about it Baltazzar.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: The watch word.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: O! the word let it be treason;
When we cry treason, break ope chamber doors:
Kill Phillip and the Cardinal; Hence

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: I fly.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Murder, now ride in triumph, darkness, horror;
Thus I invoke your aid, your Act begin;
Night is a glorious Robe, for the ugliest sin.

div.head: Act. II. Scena. IV.
div.stage: Enter Cole and Crab in Trouses, the Cardinall in one of their weeds, and Philip putting on the other.

sp.speaker: Both Friers.
sp.l: PUt on my Lord, and fly or else you die.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will not, I will die first; Cardinal,
Prithee good Cardinal pluck off, Eriers, slave,
Murder us two, he shall not by this sword.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My Lord, you will endanger both our lives.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I care not; I will kill some before I die:
Away, 'sheart take your rags; Moor, Devil, come.

sp.speaker: 2. Friers.
sp.l: My Lord put on, or else.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Gods foot come help:

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Ambitious villain. Philip, let us fly
Into the chamber of the Mother Queen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thunder, beat down the lodgings.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Else let us break into the chamber of the King:

sp.speaker: Phillip.
sp.l: Agreed,
A pox upon those lowsy gabardines,
Agreed, I am for you Moor; stand side by side,
Come, hands off, leave your ducking, hell cannot fright,
Their spirits that do desperately fight.

sp.speaker: Cole
sp.l: You are too rash, you are too hot,
Wild desperateness doth valour blot;
The lodging of the King is beset,
With staring faces black as Jet,
And hearts of Iron, your deaths are vowed
If you fly that way, therefore shroud,
Your body in Friar Coles gray weed,
Foris it not madness man to bleed:
When you may scape untouched away,
Here is hell, here is heaven, here if you stay
You are gon, you are gon, Friar Crab and I,
Will here dance friskin whilst you fly:
Gag us, bind us, come put on
The Gag is too wide, so gon, gon, gon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O! well, I will come again, Lord Cardinal
Take you your Castle, I will to Portugall:
I vow I will come again, and if I do:

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Nay good my Lord!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Black Devil I will conjure you.

div.head: Act. II. Scena. V.
div.stage: To the Friers making a noise, gagg'd and bound, Enter Eleazar, Zarack, Baltazar, and other Moors, all with their Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: GUard all the passages, Zarack stand there,
There Baltazar, there you, the Friars,
Where have you placed the Friars?

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: My Lord a noise.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: The Friars are gagged and bound.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: It is Phil. and the Cardinal, shoot; ha stay!
Unbind them; where is Mendoza, and the Prince.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Sancta Maria who can tell:
By Peters keys they bound us well,
And having cracked our shaven crowns,
They have escaped you in our gowns.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Escaped; escaped away? I am glad, it is good,
I would their arms may turn to Eagles wings,
To fly us swift, as time sweet air give way,
Winds leave your two and thirty palaces,
And meeting all in one, join all your might,
To give them speedy and a prosperous flight,
Escaped Friars, which way?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: This way.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Good: Alas; what sin is it to shed innocent blood;
For look you holy men, it is the King;
The King, the King, see Friars sulphury wrath
Having once entered into Royal breasts:
Mark how it burns, the Queen Philip's mother;
O! most unnatural, will have you two
Divulge abroad that he is a bastard. O!
Will you do it.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: What says my brother Friar?

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: A Princes love is balm, their wrath a fire:

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: It is true, but yet I will publish no such thing;
What fool would lose his soul, to please a King?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Keep there, good there, yet for it wounds my soul,
To see the miserablest wretch to bleed.
I counsel you (in care unto your lives)
To obey the mother Queen, for by my life
I think she has been pricked, her conscience
O! it has stung her, for some fact misdone,
She would not else disgrace herself and son
Do it therefore, hark, she will work your deaths else, hate
Bred in a woman is insatiate.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Brother Cole? Zeal sets me in a flame,
I will do it.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: And I,
His baseness we will proclaim

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Do, and be damned; Zarack and Baltazar.
Dog them at the heels, and when their poisonous breath
Hath scattered this infection, on the hearts
Of credulous Spaniards, here reward them thus,
Slaves too much trusted do grow dangerous;
Why this shall feed,
And fat suspicion, and my policy
I will ring through all the Court, this loud alarum:
That they contrived the murder of the King,
The Qu. and me; and being undermined,
To scape the blowing up, they fled. O good!
There, there, thou there, cry treason; each one take
A several door, your cries my music make.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: Where is the King? treason pursues him:

div.stage: Enter Alvero in his shirt, his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Where is the sleepy Qu. Rise, rise, and arm, against the hand of treason.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Whence comes this sound of treason?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who frights our quiet slumbers,

div.stage: Enter King in his shirt, his sword drawn.

sp.l: With this heavy noise:

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Was it a dream? or did the sound

div.stage: Enter Queen in her night attire.

sp.l: Of monster treason call me from my rest.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who raised this rumour Eleaz. you?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I did my Liege, and still continue it,
Both for your safety, and mine own discharge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Whence comes the ground then?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: from the Cardinal,
And the young Prince, who bearing in his mind
The true Idea of his late disgrace,
In putting him from the Protectorship,
And envying the advancement of the Moor
Determined this night to murder you;
And for your Highness lodged within my Castle,
They would have laid the murder on my head.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Cardinal, and my Brother bring them forth
Their lives shall answer this ambitious practice.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Alas my Lord it is impossible,
For when they saw I had discovered them
They trained two harmless Friars to their lodgings;
Disrobed them, gagged them, bound them to two posts,
And in their habits did escape the Castle.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That Cardinal, is all ambition,
And from him doth our Brother gather heart.

sp.speaker: Que. Mo.
sp.l: The ambition of the one infects the other,
And in a word they both are dangerous;
But might your mothers counsel stand force,
I would advise you send the trusty Moor
To fetch them back, before they had seduced
The squint eyed multitude from true allegiance,
And drawn them to their dangerous faction.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It shall be so, therefore my States best prop,
Within whose bosom I durst trust my life,
Both for my safety and thine own discharge.
Fetch back those traitors, and till your return
Ourself will keep your Castle.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: My Liege; the tongue of true obedience
Most not gainsay his Sovereigns impose,
By heaven; I will not kiss the cheek of sleep,
Till I have fetched those traitors to the Court.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why; this sorts right, he gon; his beauteous wife
Shall sail into the naked arms of love.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Why, this is as it should be, he once gon,
His wife that keeps me from his marriage bed,
Shall by this hand of mine be murthered.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This storm is well nigh past the swelling clouds,
That hang so full of treason by the wind,
In awful Majesty are scattered.
Then each man to his rest; good night sweet friend,
Whilst thou pursuest the traitors that are fled,
Fernando means to warm thy marriage bed.

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: Many good nights, consume and damn your souls.
I know he means to Cuckold me this night;
Yet do I know no means to hinder it.
Besides, who know, whether the lustful King
Having my wife and Castle at command,
Will ever make surrender back again:
But if he do not, with my falchions point
I will lance those swelling veins in which hot lust
Does keep his Revels, and with that warm blood
Where Venus's bastard cooled his sweltering spleen,
Wash the disgrace from Eleazars brows.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: DEar Eleazar;

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.l: If they lock the gates
I will toss a ball of wild-fire over the walls.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Husband, sweet husband:

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Or else swim over the moat,
And make a breach through the flinty sides
Of the rebellious walls:

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Hear me, dear heart.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Or undermine the chamber where they lie,
And by the violent strength of gunpowder,
Blow up the Castle, and the incestuous couch,
In which lust wallows; but my labouring thoughts,
Wading too deep in bottomless extremes;
Do drown themselves in their own stratagems.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Sweet husband! dwell not upon circumstance,
When weeping sorrow like an Advocate
Importunes you for aid; look in mine eyes
There you shall see dim grief swimming in tears,
Invocating succour. O succour!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Succour. Zounds for what?

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: To shield me from Fernando's unchaste love,
Who with incessant prayers importuned me.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: To lie with you I know it.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Then seek some means how to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: It is possible; for to the end that his unbridled lust
Might have more free access unto thy bed,
This night he hath enjoined me
To fetch back Philip and the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Then this ensuing night shall give an end
To all my sorrows, for before foul lust
Shall soil the fair complexion of mine honour,
This hand shall rob Maria of her life.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Not so dear soul, for in extremities
Choose out the least, and ere the hand of death
Should suck this Ivory palace of thy life:
Embrace my counsel, and receive this poison
Which in the instant he attempts thy love,
Then give it him: do, do,
Do poison him, he gone, thou art next;
Be sound in resolution; and farewell;
By one, and one, I will ship you all to hell.
Spain I will drown thee with thine own proud blood,
Then make an ark of carcasses farewell.
Revenge and I will sail in blood to hell.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Poison the King, Alas my trembling hand
Would let the poison fall, and through my cheeks
Fear suited in a bloodless livery,
Would make the world acquainted with my guilt,
But thanks prevention, I have found a means
Both to preserve my Royal Sovereigns life,
And keep myself a true and Loyal wife.

div.trailer: The end of the second Act.

div.head: Scena I.
div.stage: Enter Queen Mother, with a Torch, solus.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: FAir eldest child of love, thou spotless night,
Empress of silence, and the Queen of sleep;
Who with thy black cheeks pure complexion,
Makest lovers eyes enamoured of thy beauty:
Thou art like my Moor, therefore will I adore thee,
For lending me this opportunity,
O with the soft skinned Negro! heavens keep back
The saucy staring day from the worlds eye,
Until my Eleazar make return;
Then in his Castle shall he find his wife,
Transformed into a strumpet by my son;
Then shall he hate her whom he would not kill?
Then shall I kill her whom I cannot love?
The King is sporting with his Concubine.
Blush not my boy, be bold like me thy mother,
But their delights torture my soul like Devils,
Except her shame be seen: Wherefore awake
Christophero, Verdugo, raise the Court,
Arise you Peers of Spain, Alvaro rise,
Preserve your country from base infamies.

div.stage: Enter severally at severall doors, with lights and Rapiers drawn, Alvero, Roderigo, and Christophero, with others.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Who raised these exclamations through the Court?

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Sheath up your Swords, you need not swords, but eyes
To intercept this treason.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: What is the treason?
Who are traitors? ring the larum bell;
Cry arm through all the City; once before
The horrid sound of treason did affright
Our sleeping spirits.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Stay, you need not cry arm
Arm, for this black deed
Works treason to your King, to me; to you,
To Spain, and all that shall in Spain ensue.
This night Maria (Eleazars wife)
Hath drawn the King by her Lascivious looks
Privately to a banquet, I unseen
Stood and beheld him in him in her lustful arms.
O God! shall bastards wear Spain's Diadem?
If you can kneel to baseness, vex them not;
If you disdain to kneel, wash of this blot.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Let us break into the chamber and surprise her?

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: O miserable me! do, do, break in,
My Country shall not blush at my child's sin.

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: Delay is nurse to danger, follow me,
Come you and witness to her villainy.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: Hapless Alvero, how art thou undone,
In a light daughter, and a stubborn son.

div.head: Act. III. Scena II.
div.stage: Enter King with his Rapier drawn in one hand, leading Maria seeming affrighted in th' other.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: O! kill me ere you stain my chastity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My hand holds death, but love sits in mine eye,
Exclaim not dear Maria, do but hear me;
Though thus in dead of night as I do now
The lustful Tarquin stole to the chaste bed
Of Collatines fair wife, yet shalt thou be
No Lucrece, nor thy King a Romane slave,
To make rude villainy thine honours grave.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Why from my bed have you thus frighted me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: To let thee view a bloody horrid Tragedy.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Begin it then, I will gladly lose my life,
Rather than be an Emperor's Concubine.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: By my high birth I swear thou shalt be none,
The Tragedy I will write with my own hand,
A King shall act it, and a King shall die;
Except sweet mercies beam shine from thine eye.
If this affright thee it shall sleep forever,
If still thou hate me, thus this Noble blade,
This Royal purple temple shall invade.

sp.speaker: Maria
sp.l: My husband is from hence, for his sake spare me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thy husband is no Spaniard, thou art one,
So is Fernando, then for countries sake
Let me not spare thee, on thy husbands face
Eternal night in gloomy shades doth dwell;
But I will look on thee like the gilded Sun,
When to the west his fiery horses run.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: True, true, you look on me with Sun set eyes,
For by beholding you my glory dies.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Call me thy morning then, for like the morn,
In pride Maria shall through Spain be born.
This music I prepared thine ears,
Love me and thou shalt hear no other sounds,
Lo here is a banquet set with mine own hands;
Love me, and thou shalt feast thee like a Queen:
I might command thee being thy Sovereign;
But love me and I will kneel and sue to thee,
And circle this white forehead with the Crown
Of Castile, Portugall, and Arragon,
And all those petty Kingdoms which do bow
Their tributary knees to Philip's heir.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: I cannot love you whilst my husband lives:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I will send him to the wars, and in the front
Of some main army shall he nobly die.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: I cannot love you if you murder him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: For thy sake then, I will call a Parliament
And banish by a law all Moors from Spain.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: I will wander with him into banishment.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It shall be death for any Negroes hand,
To touch the beauty of a Spanish dame.
Come, come, what needs such cavils with a King?
Night blinds all Jealous eyes, and we may play,
Carouse that bowl to me, I will pledge all this,
Being down, we will make it more sweet with a kiss.
Begin, I will lock all doors, begin Spain's Queen,
Loves banquet is most sweet, when it is least seen.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: O thou conserver of my honours life!
Instead of poisoning him, drown him in sleep,
Because I will quench the flames of wild desire,
I will drink this off, let fire conquer loves fire.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Were love himself in real substance here,
Thus would I drink him down, let your sweet strings,
Speak louder (pleasure is but a slave to Kings)
In which love swim. Maria kiss thy King,
Circle me in this ring of Ivory.
O! I grow dull, and the cold hand of sleep
Hath thrust his Icy fingers in my breast,
And made a frost within me; sweet, one kiss
To thaw this deadness that congeals my soul.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Your Majesty hath overwatched yourself,
He sleeps already, not the sleep of death;
But a sweet slumber, which the powerful drug
Instilled through all his spirits. O! bright day
Bring home my dear Lord, ere his King awake,
Else of his unstained bed he will shipwreck make.

div.stage: Enter Oberon, and Fairyes dancing before him, and musick with them.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: O me! what shapes are these?

sp.speaker: Oberon.
sp.l: Stay, stay, Maria.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: My Sovereign Lord awake, save poor Maria.

sp.speaker: Oberon.
sp.l: He cannot save thee, save that pain,
Before he wake thou shalt be slain;
His mothers hand shall stop thy breath,
Thinking her own son is done to death:
And she that takes away thy life,
Does it to be thy husbands wife.
Adieu Maria, we must hence,
Embrace thine end with patience;
Elves and Fairies make no stand,
Till you come in Fairy Land.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Fairies or Devils, whatsoever you be,
Thus will I hide me from your company.

div.head: Act. III. Scena. III.
div.stage: To her, Enter Queen Mother suddainly, with Alvaro, and Roderigo, with Rapiers.

sp.speaker: Q Mo.
sp.l: LAy hold upon the strumpet, where is the King?
Fernando, son; ah me your King is dead!
Lay hand upon the murderess.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Imperious Queen, I am as free from murder as thyself,
Which I will prove, if you will hear me speak:
The King is living.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: If he lived his breath would beat within his breast.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: The life he leads, Maria thou shalt soon participate.

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: O father save me!

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: thou art no child of mine, hadst thou been owner of Alvero's spirit.
Thy heart would not have enterained a thought
That had conversed with murder: yet mine eyes
(However my tongue want words) brim full with tears,
Entreat her further trial.

sp.speaker: Verdugo.
sp.l: To what end: here lies her trial: from this royal breast
Hath she stolen all comfort, all the life
Of every bosom in the Realm of Spain.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: She is both a traitor and murderess.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: I will have her forthwith strangled.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Hear her speak.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: To heaven let her complain if she have wrong,
I murder but the murderess of my son.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: We murder the murderess of our King.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Ah me my child o! O cease your torturing!

sp.speaker: Maria.
sp.l: Heaven ope the windows, that my spotless soul,
Riding upon the wings of innocence,
May enter Paradise, Fairies farewell;
Fernandoes death in mine you did foretell.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Who calls Fernando? love, Maria, speak:
O! whither art thou fled? whence flow these waters
That fall like winter storms, from the drowned eyes.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: From my Maria's death!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Maria dead?
Damned be the soul to hell that stopped her breath;
Maria, O me who durst murder her?

sp.speaker: Q. M.
sp.l: I thought my dear Fernando had been dead,
And in my indignation murdered her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I was not dead until you murdered me
By killing fair Maria.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Gentle son.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Ungentle mother, you a deed have done,
Of so much ruth that no succeeding age
Can ever clear you of; O my dear love,
Yet heavens can witness thou wert never mine:
Spain's wonder was Maria.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Sweet have done:

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Have done! for what, for shedding zealous tears
Over the tomb of virtues chastity;
You cry have done, now I am doing good,
But cried do on, when you were shedding blood:
Have you done mother; yes, yes, you have done,
That which will undo your unhappy son.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: These words become you not my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: These words become not me, no more it did
Become you Lords to be mute standers by,
When lustful fury ravished chastity.
It ill becomes me to lament her death,
But it became you well to stop her breath:
Had she been fair and not so virtuous,
This deed had not been half so impious.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: But she was fair in virtue, virtuous fair, o me!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O me! she was true honours heir.
Hence beldam from my presence, all fly hence,
You are all murderers, come poor innocence,
Clasp thy cold hand in mine, for here I will lie,
And since I lived for her, for her I will die.

div.head: Act. III. Scena. IV.
div.stage: Enter Eleazar with a Torch and Rapier drawn.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: BAr up my Castle Gates; fire and confusion
Shall girt these Spanish Curs; was I for this,
Sent to raise power against a fugitive:
To have my wife deflowered. Zounds where is my wife,
My slaves cry out, she is dallying with the King?
Stand by, where is your King? Eleazars bed shall
Scorn to be an Emperor's brothelry.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Be patient Eleazar, here is the King,

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Patience and I am foes, where is my Maria?

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Here is her hapless coarse that was Maria.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Here lies Maria's body, here her grave,
Her dead heart in my breast a tomb shall have.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: Now by the proud complexion of my cheeks,
Taken from the kisses of the amorous sun;
Were he ten thousand Kings that slew my love,
Thus should my hand (plumed with revenges wings)
Requite mine own dishonour, and her death.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Ah me! my son.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: The King is murdered, lay hold on the damned traitor.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: In his breast that dares but dart a finger at the Moor,
I will bury this Sharp steel yet reeking warm,
With the unchaste blood of that lecher King,
That threw my wife in an untimely grave.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: She was my daughter and her timeless grave
Did swallow down my joys as deep as yours:
But thus.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: But what? bear injuries that can,
I will wear no forked crest.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Damn this black fiend, cry treason through the Court.
The King is murdered.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: He that first opes his lips, I will drive his words
Down his wide throat upon my rapiers point.
The King is murdered and I will answer it;
I am dishonoured, and I will revenge it.
Bend not your dangerous weapons at my breast:
Think where you are, this Castle is the Moors,
You are environed with a wall of flint.
The Gates are locked, Portcullises let down
If Eleaz. spend one drop of blood,

div.stage: Zarack and Baltazar above with Calivers.

sp.l: On those high turret tops my slaves stand armed,
And shall confound your souls with murdering shot.
Or if you murder me, yet under ground
A villain that for me will dig to hell,
Stands with a burning linstock in his fist,
Who firing gunpowder up in the air,
Shall fling your torn and mangled carcasses.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: O! sheath your weapons, though my son be slain,
Yet save yourselves, choose a new Sovereign.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Prince Philip is our Sovereign, choose him King.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Prince Philip shall not be my Sovereign,
Philip is a bastard, and Fernando is dead;
Mendoza sweats to wear Spain's Diadem,
Philip hath sworn confusion to this Realm,
They both are up in arms, wars flames do shine
Like lightning in the air, wherefore my Lords
Look well on Eleazar; value me not by my sun-burnt
Cheek, but by my birth; nor by
My birth, but by my loss of blood,
Which I have sacrificed in Spain's defence.
Then look on Philip, and the Cardinal:
Look on those gaping curs, whose wide throats
Stand stretched wide open like the gates of death,
To swallow you, your country, children, wives.
Philip cries fire and blood, the Cardinal
Cries likewise fire and blood, I will quench those flames,
The Moor cries blood and fire, and that shall burn
Till Castile like proud Troy to Cinders turn.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Lay by these Ambages, what seeks the Moor?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A Kingdom, Castiles crown.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: Peace devil for shame.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Peace doting Lord for shame, O misery!
When Indian slaves thirst after Empery;
Princes and Peers of Spain we are beset,
With horror on each side; you deny him,
Death stands at all our backs, we cannot fly him.
Crown Philip King, The Crown upon his head,
Will prove a fiery Meteor, War and vengeance
And desolation will invade our land,
Besides Prince Philip is a bastard born.
O! give me leave to blush at mine own shame;
But I for love to you, love to fair Spain,
Choose rather to rip up a Queens disgrace,
Than by concealing it to set the Crown
Upon a bastards head. Wherefore my Lords
By my consent crown that proud Blackamoor,
Since Spain's bright glory must so soon grow dim;
Since it must end, let it end all in him.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Eleazar shall be King.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: O treachery! have you so soon razed out Fernando's love;
So soon forgot the duty of true Peers;
So soon, so soon buried a mothers name,
That you will crown him King that slew your King.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Will you hear him or me, who shall be King.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Eleazar shall be Castiles Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Do, do; make haste to crown him! Lords adieu.
Here hell must be when the Devil governs you.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: By heavens great Star, which Indians do adore,
But that I hate to hear the giddy world;
Shame that I waded to a Crown through; blood,
I would not digest his pills, but since my Lords
You have chosen Eleazar for your King?
Invest me with a general applause.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Live Eleazar, Castiles Royal King.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: A villain and a base born fugitive.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.l: A bloody tyrant, an usurping slave.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Thanks to you all, it is not the Spanish Crown
That Eleazar strives for, but Spain's peace.
Amongst you I will divide her Empery;
Christofero shall wear Granado's Crown;
To Roderigo I will give Arragon:
Naples, Navar and fair Jerusalem,
I will give to other three, and then our vice Roys,
Shall Shine about our bright Castilian crown,
As stars about the Sun. Cry all, arm, arm;
Prince Philip and the Cardinal do ride
Like Jove in thunder, in a storm we will meet them;
Go levy powers, if any man must fall,
My death shall first begin the funeral.

div.head: Act. III. Scena. V.
div.stage: Enter Zarack and Baltazar with Calivers.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: IS thy cock ready, and thy powder dry.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: My cock stands perching, like a cock of the game;
With a red cole for his crest instead of a comb;
And for my powder, it is but touch and take.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: I have tickling gear too, anon I will cry here I have it,
And yonder I see it; But Zarack is it policy for us
To kill these bald-pates.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Is it policy for us to save ourselves,
If they live, we die. Is it not wisdom then
To send them to heaven, rather than be sent ourselves;
Come you black slave, be resolute. This way they come,
Here they will stand, and yonder will I stand.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: And in yonder hole I.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Our amiable faces cannot be seen, if we keep close:
Therefore hide your cocks head, left his burning cocks-comb betray us.
But soft, which of the two shall be thy white.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: That black villain Friar Cole.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: I shall have a sharp piece of service.
Friar Crab shall be my man.
Farewell and be resolute.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: Zounds Zarack I shall never have the heart to do it.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: You rogue think who commands, Eleazar.
Who shall rise Baltazar?
Who shall die, a lousy Friar?
Who shall live our good Lord and Master?
The Negro King of Spain.

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: Cole, thou art but a dead man,
And shall turn to ashes.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Crab, here is that shall make vinegar of thy carcass.

div.stage: Enter Crab and Cole, two Friers, with a rout of Stinkards following them.

sp.speaker: Frier Crab.
sp.l: Aye brother it is best, so now we have drawn them to a head,
We will begin here in the market place.
Tut so long as we be commanded by the Mother Queen.
We will say her son is a bastard, and he were ten Philips.

sp.speaker: F. Cole.
sp.l: Take you one market form, I will take another.

sp.speaker: F. Crab.
sp.l: No, Gods-so; we must both keep one form.

sp.speaker: F. Cole.
sp.l: Aye in oration, but not in station mount, mount?
Well my masters, you know him not so well as I; on my word
Friar Crab is a sour fellow:
Yet he may utter sweet doctrine by your leave; but what
Think you of Friar Cole?
He all fire, and he be kindled once a hot Catholic.
And you mark him, he has a zealous nose,
And richly inflamed.
Peace you Rogues, now they begin.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Incipe Frater?

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Non ego Domine.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Nec ego.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Quare?

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Quia?

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Quaeso,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Here is a queasy beginning methinks; silence, silence.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Brethren, Citizens, and market folks of Sivell.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Well beloved and honoured Castilians.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: It is not unknown to you!

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: I am sure you are not ignorant.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: How villainous and strong?

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: How monstrous and huge?

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: The faction of Prince Philip is;

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Philip that is a bastard:

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Philip that is a bastard.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Philip that killed your King.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Only to make himself King.

sp.speaker: Cole
sp.l: And by Gads blessed Lady you are all damned, and you suffer it.
Friar Cole says true, he speaks out of the heat of his zeal;
Look how he glows.
Well Friar Crab for my money, he has set my teeth an edge
Against this bastard.
O! his words are like Vergis, to whet a man's stomach.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Silence, silence.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Now contrariwise.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Your Noble King the Moor.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Is a valiant Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: A Noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: An honourable Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: A fair black Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: A friend to Castilians.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: A Champion for Castilians.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: A man fit to be King.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: If he were not borne down by him that would be King,
Who (as I said before) is a bastard, and no King.
What think you my masters? do you mark his words well.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: Further compare them together.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: 'sblood, there is no comparison between them.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Nay, but hear us good Country men.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hear Friar Cole, hear Friar Cole.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Set that bastard and Eleazar together:
How? mean you, by the ears.

sp.speaker: Crab.
sp.l: No, but compare them.

sp.speaker: Cole.
sp.l: Do but compare them.
Zounds, we say again comparisons are odious.
But say on, say on.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Treason, treason, every man shift for himself.
This is Philips treason. Arm, Arm, Arm.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: ZArack and Baltazar, are they despatched?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: We saw them sprawl, and turn up the white of the eye.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: So shall they perish, that lay countermines;
To erosse our high designments: by their habits,
The Cardinal and Philip scaped our nets.
And by your hands they tasted our revenge.
Here come the Queen, away! under our wings,
You shall stand safe, and brave the proudest Kings.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: O! fly my Eleazar, save thy lite.
Else point a guard about thee, the mad people
Tempestuous like the Sea run up and down
Some crying kill the bastard, some the Moor;
Some cry, God save King Philip; and some cry,
God save the Moor; some others, he shall die.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Are these your fears, thus blow them into air.
I rush amongst the thickest of their crowds,
And with a countenance Majestical,
Like the Imperious Sun dispersed their clouds;
I have perfumed the rankness of their breath,
And by the magic of true eloquence,
Transformed this many headed Cerberus,
This pied Chameleon, this beast multitude,
Whose power consists in number, pride in threats;
Yet melt like snow when Majesty shines forth
This heap of fools, who crowding in huge, swarms,
Stood at our Court gates like a heap of dung,
Reeking and shouting out contagious breath
of power to poison all the elements;
This Wolf I held by the ears, and made him tame,
And made him tremble at the Moors great name.
No, we must combat with a grimmer foe,
That damned Mendoza over-turns our hopes.
He loves you dearly.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.p:
By his secret Letters he hath entreated
me in some disguise to leave the Court, and fly into his arms.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: The world cannot devise a stratagem
Sooner to throw confusion on his pride:
Subscribe to his desires, and in dead night
Steal to his Castle, swear to him his love
Hath drawn you thither; undermine his soul,
And learn what villainies are there laid up,
Then for your pleasure walk to take the air:
Near to the Castle I will in ambush lie,
And seem by force to take you prisoner;
This done, I have a practice plotted here,
Shall rid him of his life, and us of fear:
About it madam, this is all in all;
We cannot stand unless Mendoza fall.

div.head: Act. IV.
Scena. I.
div.stage: Enter Emanuel King of Portugal, Prince Philip, Mendoza, Alvaro, with Drums and Souldiers marching.

sp.speaker: King Port.
sp.l: POor Spain, how is the body of thy peace
Mangled and torn by an ambitious Moor!
How is thy Prince and Counsellors abused,
And trodden under the base foot of scorn:
Wronged Lords, Emanuel of Portugal partakes
A falling share in all your miseries:
And though the tardy-hand of slow delay
With-held us from preventing your mishaps;
Yet shall revenge dart black confusion
Into the bosom of that damned fiend.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But is it possible our Mother Queen
Should countenance his ambition.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Her advice is as a Steers-man to direct his course.
Besides, as we by circumstance have learnt,
She means to marry him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then here upon my knees
I pluck allegiance from her; all that love
Which by in native duty I did owe her,
Shall henceforth be converted into hate.
This will confirm the worlds opinion
That I am base born, and the damned Moor
Had interest in my birth, this wrong alone
Gives new fire to the cinders of my rage:
I may be well transformed from what I am,
When a black devil is husband to my dam.

sp.speaker: K. Port.
sp.l: Prince, let thy rage give way to patience,
And set a velvet brow upon the face
Of wrinkled anger, our keen swords,
Must right these wrongs, and not light airy words.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Yet words may make the edge of rage more sharp,
And whet a blunted courage with revenge.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Here is none wants whetting, for our keen resolves
Are steeled unto the back with double wrongs;
Wrongs that would make a handless man take arms;
Wrongs that would make a coward resolute.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Why then join all our several wrongs in one,
And from these wrongs assume a firm resolve,
To send this devil to damnation.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I hear the sound of his approaching march,
Stand fair; Saint Jaques for the right of Spain.

div.stage: To them, Enter the Moor, Roderigo, Christofero, with drums, colours, and souldiers, marching bravely.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Bastard of Spain?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou true stamped son of hell,
Thy pedigree is written in thy face.

div.stage: Alarum, and a Battail, the Moor prevails: All Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: MOve forward, with your main battalion,
Or else all is lost.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I will not move a foot.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: 'sheart, will you lose the day.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: You lose your wits,
You are mad, it is no policy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You lie.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Lie?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Lie, a pox upon it Cardinal come on,
Second the desperate vanguard which is mine,
And where I will die or win, follow my sword
The bloody way I lead it, or by heaven
I will play the Devil, and mar all, we will turn our backs
Upon thee Moors, and set on thee; I thee,
Thee Cardinal, 'sheart thee.

sp.speaker: Cardi.
sp.l: Your desperate arm
Hath almost thrust quite through the heart of hope;
Our fortunes lie a-bleeding by your rash and violent
Onset.
