sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O! o! 'slife, 'sfoot, will you fight?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: We will not hazard all upon one cast.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: You will not?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Coward.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: By deeds I will try,
Whether your venomous tongue says true, fare well.
Courage shines both in this, and policy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To save thy skin whole, that is thy policy;
You whoreson fat-chopped guts. I will melt away
That larded body by the heat of fight,
Which I will compel thee to, or else by flying;
To work which I will give way to the proud foe,
Whilst I stand laughing to behold thee run.
Cardinal I will do it, I will do it, a Moor, a Moor,
Philip cries a Moor, holla! ha! whoo!

sp.speaker: King of Port.
sp.l: Prince, Philip, Philip,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here, plague where is the Moor.

sp.speaker: K. Port.
sp.l: The Moor is a Devil, never did horrid fiend
Compelled by some Magicians mighty charm,
Break through the prisons of the solid earth,
With more strange horror, than this Prince of hell,
This damned Negro Lion-like doth rush,
Through all, and spite of all knit opposition.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Puh! puh! where? Where? I will meet him, where? you mad me.
It is not his arm,
That acts such wonders, but our cowardice,
This Cardinal, o! this Cardinal is a slave.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.l: Sound a retreat, or else the day is lost;

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I will beat that dog to death, that sounds; retreat.

sp.speaker: K. Port.
sp.l: Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will tear his heart out, that dares name but Sound.

sp.speaker: K. Port.
sp.l: Sound a retreat.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who is that? you tempt my sword Sir.
Continue this alarum, fight pell mell?
Fight, kill, be damned? this fat-back Coward Cardinal,
Lies heavy on my shoulders; this, I this
Shall fling him off: Sound a retreat! Zounds, you mad me.
Ambition plumes the Moor, whilst black despair
Offering to tear from him the Diadem
Which he usurps, make, him to cry at all,
And to act deeds beyond astonishment;
But Philip is the night that darks his glories,
This swords yet reeking with his Negro's blood,
Being grasped by equity, and this strong arm
Shall through and through.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Away then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: From before me;
Stay, stand, stand fast, fight A Moor, a Moor.

div.head: Act. IV. Scena. III.
div.stage: To them enter Eleazar, Zarack, Baltazar, Roderigo, Christofero, and others, they fight, Moors are all beat in, Exeunt omnes, manet Eleazar weary; staies, a Moor lies slain.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: O for more work, more souls to post to hell;
That I might pile up Charons boat so full,
Until it topple over, O it would be sport
To see them sprawl through the black slimy lake.
Ha, ha; there is one going thither, sirrah, you,
You slave, who killed thee? how he grins! this breast,
Had it been tempered, and made proof like mine,
It never would have been a mark for fools
To hit afar off with their dastard bullets.
But thou didst well, thou knewest I was thy Lord;
And out of love and duty to me here,
Where I fell weary, thou laidest down thyself
To bear me up, thus: God a-mercy slave.
A King for this shall give thee a rich grave.

div.stage: As he sits down, enter Philip with a broken sword.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I will wear thee to the pommel, but I will find
The subject of mine honour and revenge.
Moor it is for thee I seek; Come now, now take me
At good advantage: speak, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fate and revenge I thank you rise.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: Leave and live.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Villain, it is Philippe that bids rise.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: It had been good for thee to have hid thy name.
For the discovery, like to a dangerous charm,
Hurts him that finds it, wherefore does those blood hounds
Thy rage and valour chase me?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: With that! what a blunt axe? thinkest thou I will let
Thy fury take a full blow at this head,
Having these arms, be wise; go change thy weapon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O, Sir!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I will stay thy coming.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou wilt be damned first.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: By all our Indian gods.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Puh, never swear;
Thou knowest it is for a kingdom which we fight;
And for that who will not venture to hellgates.
Come Moor, I am armed with more than complete steel,
The justice of my quarrel: when I look
Upon my Fathers wrongs, my brothers wounds,
My mothers infamy, Spain's misery,
And lay my finger here, O! it is too dull,
To let out blood enough to quench them all.
But when I see your face, and know what fears.
Hang on thy troubled soul, like leaden weights,
To make it sink; I know this fingers touch
Has strength to throw thee down, I know this iron
Is sharp and long enough to reach that head.
Fly not dive, if thou do?

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: How fly; O bast!

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Come then

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Stay Philip, whosoever begat thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why slave, a King begat me.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: May be so.
But I will be sworn thy mother was a Queen;
For her sake will I kill thee nobly:
Fling me thy sword, there is mine, I scorn to strike
A man disarmed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For this dishonouring me
I will give thee one stab more.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I will run away,
Unless thou change that weapon, or take mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'sheart, stay, and if you dare,
Do as I do, oppose thy naked breast
Against this poniard; see, here is this for thine.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I am for thee Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Come, nay take more ground,
That with a full career thou mayst strike home.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Thou wilt run away then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Thou wilt run away then.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Faith, I will, but first on this I will bear
Thy panting heart, thy head upon thy spear.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Come.

div.stage: Enter on both sides, Cardinall, and King of Portugal, on the one side, and Moors on the other side.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Side upon the Moors.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Side upon the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold Cardinal, strike not any of our side,

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hold Moors, strike not any of our side,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: we two will close this battle.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Come, agreed.
Stand armies and give aim, whilst we two bleed.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: With poniards; it is too desperate, dear Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Away, have at the Moor, 'sheart let me come?

sp.speaker: K. Port.
sp.l: Be armed with manly weapons, it is for slaves,
To dig their own and such unworthy graves.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I am for thee any way, thus, or see thus,
Here try the vigour of thy sinewy arm,
The day is ours already, brainless heads
And bleeding bodies like a crown do stand,
About the temples of our victory.
Yet Spaniards if you dare we will fight it out,
Thus man to man alone, I will first begin,
And conquer, or in blood wade up to the chin.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let not a weapon stir, but his and mine.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Nor on this side, conquest in blood shall shine.

div.stage: Alarum. They fight a Combate, The Moor is struck down, which his side seeing, step all in and rescue him; The rest joine and drive in the Moors. Alarum continuing, Spaniards and Moors with drums and colours flye over the stage, persued by Philip, Cardinall, King Port. And others. Enter Zarack Christofero, and Eleazar at severall doors.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.l: Where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Where is our Sovereign?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: What news brings Zarack and Christofero?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: O fly my Lord! fly; for the day is lost.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: There are three hundred and odd days in a year,
And cannot we lose one of them, come fight.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.l: The Lords have left us, and the soldiers faint,
You are round beset with proud fierce enemies;
Death cannot be prevented but by flight?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: He shall Christofero. I have yet left,
One stratagem that in despite of fate,
Shall turn the wheel of war about once more,
The Mother Queen hath all this while sate sadly,
Within our tent, expecting to whose bosom,
White winged peace and victory will fly,
Her have I used as a fit property,
To stop this dangerous current; her have I sent,
Armed with loves magic to enchant the Cardinal;
And bind revenge down with resistless charms.
By this time does she hang about his neck,
And by the witchcraft of a cunning kiss;
Has she disarmed him, hark, they sound
She has prevailed, a woman's tongue and eye;
Are weapons stronger than Artillery.

div.head: Act. IV Scena. IV.
div.stage: Enter Cardinall, Queen Mother. Souldiers, drums, and colours.

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: BY all those sighs which thou (like passionate tunes)
Hast often to my dull ears offered,
By all thy hopes to enjoy my royal Bed;
By all those mourning lines which thou hast sent,
Weeping in black to tell thy languishment:
By loves best richest treasure, which I swear,
I will bestow, and which none else shall wear,
As the most prized Jewel, but thyself,
By that bright fire which flaming through thine eyes;
From thy love scorched bosom does arise.
I do conjure thee, let no churlish sound,
With wars lewd horror my desires confound;
Dear, dear Mendoza, thus I do entreat,
That still thou wouldst continue this retreat;
I will hang upon thee till I hear thee say,
Woman prevail; or chiding, criest away.

sp.speaker: Card
sp.l: Is there no trick in this, forged by the Moor?

sp.speaker: Qu. M.
sp.l: I would the Moors damnation were the ransom,
Of all that innocent blood, that has been shed
In this black day; I care not for the Moor,
Love to my kingdom's peace makes me put on
This habit of a suppliant; shall I speed?

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: You shall, were it to have my bosom bleed:
I have no power to spare the Negroes head,
When I behold the wounds which his black hand
Has given mine honour: but when I look on you,
I have no power to hate him, since your breath
Dissolves my frozen heart, being spent for him;
In you my life must drown itself or swim,
You have prevailed: Drum swiftly hence? call back
Our fierce pursuing troops, that run to catch
The laurel wreath of conquest: Let it stand
A while untouched by any soldiers hand.
Away? stay you and guard us, where is the Moor?
I will lose what I have got, a victors prize,
Yielding myself a prisoner to your eyes.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Mine eyes shall quickly grant you liberty,
The Moor stays my return, I will put on wings,
And fetch him, to make peace belongs to Kings.

div.stage: As she goes out, Enter Eleazar, Zarack, Baltazar, and souldiers> well arm'd, at sight of each other all draw.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Soldiers call back the drum, we are betrayed.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Moors stand upon your guard, avoid, look back.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: What means this jealousy? Mendoza, Moor,
Lay by your weapons, and embrace the fight,
Of this, and this; begets suspicion,
Eleazar by my birth, he comes in peace,
Mendoza by mine honour so comes he.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Discharge these soldiers then.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: And these.

sp.speaker: Cardinall.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: Go.

sp.speaker: Q. M.
sp.l: Soul, rejoice to see this glorious day.

div.stage: She joins them together, they imbrace.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Your virtues work this wonder: I have met,
At her most dear command, what is your desires?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Peace and your honoured arms: how loathingly
I sounded the alarums, witness heaven
It was not to strike your breast, but to let out,
The rank blood of ambition: That Philip
Makes you his ladder, and being climbed so high
As he may reach a diadem, there you lie.
He is base begotten, that is his mothers sin.

sp.speaker: Q Mo.
sp.l: God pardon it.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Aye, amen, but he is a bastard,
And rather than I will kneel to him, I will saw
My legs off by the thighs, because I will stand
In spite of reverence: he is a bastard, he is,
And to beat down his usurpation,
I have thrown about this thunder, but Mendoza,
The people hate him for his birth,
He only leans on you, you are his pillar;
You gone, he walks on crutches, or else falls;
Then shrink from under him, are not they
Fools, that bearing others up themselves seem low,
Because they above sit high, why you do so.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: It is true.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo
sp.l: Behold this error with fixed eyes.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: It is true, well.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: O! have you found it, have you smelt
The train of powder that must blow you up,
Up into air, what air? why this, a breath,
Look you, in this time may a King meet death;
An eye to it, check it, check it.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: How! thus:
Steal from the heat of that incestuous blood,
Where ravished honour, and Philippo lies;
Leave him, divide this huge and monstrous body
Of armed Spaniards into limbs thus big;
Part man from man, send every soldier home,
I will do the like; Peace with an Olive branch
Shall fly with Dove-like wings about all Spain:
The crown which I as a good husband keep,
I will lay down upon the empty chair;
Marry you the Queen and fill it, for my part
These knees are yours, Sir.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Is this sound?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: From my heart.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: If you prove false.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: If I do, let fire fall --

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Upon thy head, and so it shall.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: All of myself is yours; soldiers be gone.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: And that way you.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: The rest I will divide:
The Lords shall be convented.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Let us meet.

sp.speaker: Qu Mo.
sp.l: Where.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Here anon, this is thy winding-sheets.

div.stage: The Moor walks up and down musing.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: What shape will this prodigious womb bring forth,
Which groans with such strange labour.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Why, Eleazar, art thou wrapped with joys,
Or does thy sinking policy make to shore.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Eleazar, mad man! hearest thou Moor.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Well, so; you turn my brains, you mar the face
Of my attempts in the making: for this chaos,
This lump of projects, ere it be licked over,
It is like a Bears conception; stratagems
Being but begot, and not got out, are like
Charged Cannons not discharged, they do no harm,
Nor good, true policy breeding in the brain
Is like a bar of Iron, whose ribs being broken,
And softened in the fire, you then may forge it
Into a sword to kill, or to a helmet, to defend life:
It is therefore wit to try
All fashions, ere you apparel villainy;
But, but I ha suited him, fit, fit, O fit!

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: How? prithee how?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Why thus; yet no, let us hence,
My heart is nearest of my counsel, yet,
I scarce dare trust my heart with it, what I do,
It shall look old, the hour wherein it is born,
Wonders twice seen are garments overworn.

div.head: Act. IV. Scena. V.
div.stage: Enter Cardinal at one door, Philippo half arm'd, and two souldiers following him with the rest of the armour: the Cardinal seeing him, turns back again.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: SIrrah, you Cardinal, coward, runaway:
So ho ho, what Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I am not for your lure.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For that then, O! that it had nailed thy heart
Up to the pommel to the earth; come, arm me,
Ha! 'Sfoot, when all our swords were royally guilt with blood,
When with red sweat that trickled from our wounds,
We had dearly earned a victory! when hell
Had from their hinges heaved off her iron gates
To bid the damned Moor and the devils enter;
Then to lose all, then to sound base retreat;
Why soldiers, ha?

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.l: I am glad of it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha! glad; art glad I am dishonoured?
That thou and he dishonoured.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.l: Why? my Lord;
I am glad, that you so cleanly did come off.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou hast a lean face, and a carrion heart:
A plague on him and thee too: then, 'sheart then,
To crack the very hearts-strings of our Army,
To quarter it in pieces, I could tear my hair,
And in cursing spend my soul,
Cardinal; what Judas! come, we will fight,
Till there be left but one, if I be he,
I will die a glorious death.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.l: So will I, I hope in my bed.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: Till there be but one left, my Lord, why that is now; for all our fellows are crawled home; some with one leg, some with never an arm, some with their brains beaten out, and glad they scaped so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But my dear Countrymen, you will stick to me.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: Stick! Aye my Lord, stick like Bandogs, till we be pulled off.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That is nobly said, I will lead you but to death,
Where I will have greatest share, we shall win same,
For life and that doth crown a soldiers name.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: How! to death my Lord? not I by gad's led: I have a poor wife and children at home, and if I die they beg; and do you think I will see her go up and down the wide universal world.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For every drop of blood which thou shalt lose,
Coward I will give thy wife a wedge of gold.

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: Hang him meacock, my Lord, arm yourself, I will fight for you, till I have not an eye to see the fire in my touch-hole.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be thou a King's companion, thou and I
Will dare the Cardinal, and the Moor to fight,
In single combat, shall we? ha!

sp.speaker: 2. Sould
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: We will beat them to hell gate, shall we? ha!

sp.speaker: 2. Sould.
sp.p: Hell-gate is somewhat too hot, somewhat too hot; the Porter is a knave: I would be loath to be damned for my conscience; I will knock any bodies costard, so I knock not there, my Lord; hell gates!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A pox upon such slaves.

sp.speaker: 1. Sould.
sp.p: Hang him, a peasant, my Lord, you see I am but a scrag, my Lord; my legs are not of the biggest, nor the least, nor the best that ever were stood upon, nor the worst, but they are of God's making; And for your sake, if ever we put our enemies to flight again, by Gad's lid if I run not after them like a Tiger, hoffe me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But wilt thou stand to it ere they fly? ha! wilt thou?

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.l: Will I quoth he? by this hand, and the honour of a soldier.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And by a soldiers honour I will load thee
With Spanish pistolets: to have this head,
Thy face, and all thy body, stuck with scars,
Why it is a sight more glorious, than to see
A Lady hung with Diamonds: If thou lose
A hand, I will send this after, if an arm,
I will lend thee one of mine, come then let us fight.
A mangled Lame true soldier is a gem,
Worth Cesars Empire, though fools spurn at them.

sp.speaker: 1 Soul.
sp.p:
Yet my Lord I have seen lame soldiers, not worth the crutches they leant upon, hands and arms quoth he? Zounds not I, I will double my files, or stand sentry, or so; But I will be hanged and quartered, before I will
have my members cut off.

sp.speaker: 2 Sould.
sp.l: And I too, hold thee there.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hold you both there, away you rogues, you dirt,
Thus do I tread upon you, out, begone?
One valiant is an host, fight then alone.

div.stage: Enter Cardinall>, Alvero, Christofero, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Prince Philip.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For the Crown of Spain, come all.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: We come in love and peace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But come in war:
Bring naked swords, not laurel boughs, in peace?
Plague on your rank peace, will you fight and cry
Down with the Moor, and then I am yours: I will die,
I have a heart, two arms, a soul, a head,
I will lay that down, I will venture all; 'sfoot, all
Come tread upon me, so that Moor may fall.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By heaven that Moor shall fall.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thy hand, and thine,
Give me but half your hearts, you have all mine,
By heaven, shall he fall?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Yes, upon thee
Like to the ruins of a tower, to grind
Thy body into dust, traitor, and bastard,
I do arrest thee of High treason.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Ha!
Traitor? and bastard? and by thee? my weapons?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Lay hands upon him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Aye, you are best do so.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Alvero there is the warrant to your hands,
The prisoner is committed, Lords let us part,
Look to him on your life

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Heart, heart, heart, heart,
The Devil, and his dam, the Moor, and my Mother,
Their warrant? I will not obey, Old gray beard,
Thou shalt not be my Jailer, there is no prison,
No dungeon deep enough, no grates so strong,
That can keep in a man so mad with wrong.
What dost thou weep?

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: I would fain shed a tear,
But from mine eyes so many showers are gon,
Grief drinks my tears so fast, that here is not one,
You must to prison.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Dost thou speak to me?

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: You must to prison.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And from thence to death;
I thought I should have had a tomb hung round,
With tattered colours, broken spears, I thought
My body should have fallen down, full of wounds.
But one can kill an Emperor, fool then why
Wouldst thou have many? curse, be mad, and die,

div.trailer: The end of the fourth Act.

div.head: Act. V.
Scena I.
div.stage: Enter Ronerigo, and Christofero; two bareheaded before them, Alvero, ardinall alone, Zarack, and Baltazar bearing the Crown on a cushion, Eleazar next, Queen Mother after him other Lords after her, Alvero sad, meets them.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: ALvero it is the pleasure of the King,
Of the Queen Mother, and these honoured States,
To ease you of Philip, there is a warrant
Sent to remove him to a stronger guard.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: I thank you, you shall rid me of much care.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Sit down, and take your place!

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: If I might have the place I like best, it should be my grave.

div.stage: The Moors stand aside with the Crown, Eleazar rising, takes it!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Stand in voice, reach, away!

sp.speaker: Both Moors.
sp.l: we are gon.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Princes of Spain if in this royal Court,
There sit a man, that having laid his hold,
So fast on such a jewel, and dare wear it,
In the contempt of envy as I dare,
Yet uncompelled (as freely as poor pilgrims,
Bestow their prayers) would give such wealth away;
Let such a man step forth; what do none rise?
No, no, for Kings indeed are deities.
And would not (as the sun) in brightness shine?
To be the greatest, is to be divine:
Who among millions would not be the mightest?
To sit in God-like state, to have all eyes,
Dazzled with admiration, and all tongues
Showing loud Prayers, to rob every heart
Of love, to have the strength of every arm.
A Sovereigns name, why it is a Sovereign charm.
This glory round about me hath thrown beams,
I have stood upon the top of fortunes wheel,
And backward turned the Iron screw of fate,
The destinies have spun a silken thread
About my life, yet Noble Spaniards see?
Hoc tantum tanti, thus I cast aside
The shape of Majesty and on my knee,

div.stage: Kneels: the Cardinall fetches the Crown and sets it on the chair.

sp.l: To this Imperial State lowly resign,
This usurpation, wiping off your tears,
Which stuck so hard upon me, let a hand
A right, and royal hand take up this wreath,
And guard it, right is of itself most strong,
No kingdom got by cunning can stand long.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Proceed to new election of a King.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Stay Peers of Spain, if young Philippo,
Be Philips son, then is he Philips heir,
Then must his Royal name be set in gold,
Philip is then the Diamond to that ring;
But if he be a bastard, here is his seat,
For baseness has no gall, till it grow great.
First therefore let him blood, if he must bleed,
Yet in what vein you strike him, best take heed:
The Portugall's his friend, you saw he came
At holding up a finger, armed; this peace
Rid hence his dangerous friendship, he is at home,
But when he hears, that Philip is tied up,
Yet hears not why, he will catch occasions lock,
And on that narrow bridge make shift to lead
A scrambling army through the heart of Spain,
Look to it being in, he will hardly out again.
Therefore first prove, and then proclaim him bastard.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: How shall we prove it?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: He that put him out to making,
I am sure can tell, if not,
Then she that shaped him can, here is the Queen Mother
Being pricked in conscience, and preferring Spain,
Before her own respect, will name the man,
If he be noble and a Spaniard born, he will hide,
The apparent scars of their infamies
With the white hand of marriage; that and time,
Will eat the blemish off, say? shall it?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, the saucy slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Death is too easy for such villainy.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, the saucy slave shall die.
I would he might, I know myself am clear
As is the new born Infant. Madam stand forth,
Behold to speak, shame in the grave wants sense:
Heaven with sins greatest forfeits can dispense.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: Would I were covered with the veil of night,
You might not see red shame sit on my cheek;
But being Spain's common safety stands for truth,
Hiding my weeping eyes, I blush, and say;
Philippo's father sits here.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Here! name him?

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: The Lord Mendoza did beget that son,
O! let not this dishonour further run?

sp.speaker: Alve,
sp.l: What Cardinal Mendoza?

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Yes, yes, even he.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, the saucy slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I Philips father? --

sp.speaker: Q. M.
sp.l: Nay! deny me not?
Now may a kingdom and my love be got.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Those eyes and tongue bewitch me, shame lie here;
That love has sweetest taste that is bought dear.

sp.speaker: Christo.
sp.l: What answers Lord Mendoza to the Queen?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I confess guilty, Philip is my son,
Her Majesty hath named the time and place.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: To you, but not to us, go forward Madam.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: Within the circle of twice ten years since,
Your deceased King made war in Barbary,
Won Tunis, conquered Fesse, and hand to hand,
Slew great Abdela, King of Fesse, and father
To that Barbarian Prince.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I was but young, but now methinks
I see my fathers wounds, poor Barbaria!
No more.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: In absence of my Lord mourning his want,
To me alone, being in my private walk,
I think at Salamanca; Aye, it was there;
Enters Mendoza under show of shrift,
Threatens my death if I denied his lust,
In fine by force he won me to his will,
I wept, and cried for help, but all in vain;
Mendoza there abused the bed of Spain.

sp.speaker: E'eaz
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, that saucy slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Ave.
sp.l: Why did not you complain of this vile act?

sp.speaker: Q Mo.
sp.l: Alas! I was alone, young, full of fear;
Bashful, and doubtful of my own defame;
Knowing King Philip rash and jealous,
I hid his sins, thinking to hide my shame.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: What says the Cardinal?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Such a time there was;
It is past, I will make amends with marriage,
And satisfy with Trentals, dirges, prayers,
The offended spirit of the wronged King.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, that saucy slave shall die;
O! it would seem best, it should be thus Mendoza:
She to accuse, I urge, and both conclude,
Your marriage like a comic interlude.
Lords will you hear this hateful sin confessed?
And not impose upon the ravisher death,
The due punishment, o! it must be so.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: What does the Queen desire?

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Justice, revenge,
On vile Mendoza for my ravishment:
I kiss the cold earth with my humbled knees,
From whence I will not rise, till some just hand,
Cast to the ground the Traitor Cardinal.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Stand forth Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Swells your heart so high?
Down Lecher; if you will not stand, then lie.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You have betrayed me, by my too much trust,
I never did this deed of Rape and Lust.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: Your tongue confessed it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: True, I was enticed.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Enticed? do you believe that?

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Justice Lords! sentence the Cardinal for
His hateful sin.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: We will assemble all the States of Spain,
And as they Judge, so Justice shall be done.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A guard! to prison with the Cardinal.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Damned slave my tongue shall go at liberty
To curse thee, ban that strumpet; Dogs keep off.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hist, hist, on, on.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: I cannot brook his sight.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: You must to prison, and be patient.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Weepest thou Alvero? all struck dumb? my fears,
Are that those drops will change to bloody tears.
This woman, and this Serpent.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Drag him hence.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Who dares lay hands upon me, Lords of Spain
Let your swords bail me, this false Queen did lie.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, the saucy slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I will fight with thee, damned hell-hound for my life.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Spaniard or Moor, the saucy slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: I will prove upon thy head.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: The slave shall die.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Lords stop this villains throat.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Shall die, shall die.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Hear me but speak.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Alve.
sp.l: Words are ill spent,
Where wrong sits Judge, you are armed if innocent.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Well, then I must to prison: Moor, no more:
Heavens thou art just, Prince Philip I betrayed,
And now myself fall: Guile with guile is paid.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Philip being proved a bastard; who shall sit
Upon this empty throne?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Strumpet, not you.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Strumpet! and I not sit there! who then?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Down;
Back, if she touch it she will bewitch the chair;
This throne belongs to Isabel the fair,
Bring forth the Princess dressed in royal robes,
The true affecter of Alvero's son,
Virtuous Hortenzo. Lords, behold your Queen.

div.head: Act. V. Scena. II.
div.stage: Enter Isabella led in, in royal robes. Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: THou villain! what intendest thou, savage slave?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: To advance virtue thus, and thus to tread
On lust, on murther, on adulteries head.
Look Lords upon your Sovereign Isabel,
Though all may doubt the fruits of such a Womb,
Is she not like King Philip? let her rule.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: She rule?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: She rule? I she.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: A child to sway an empire? I am her Protectress;
I will pour black curses on thy damned head,
If thou wrongest me. Lords, Lords!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Princes of Spain,
Be deaf, be blind, hear not, behold her not,
She killed my virtuous wife.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: He killed your King.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: It was in my just wrath.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: It was to get his Crown.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: His Crown! why here it is: thou slewest my Maria,
To have access to my unstained bed.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: It is true, how often have I stopped
Thy unchaste songs from passing through mine ears?
How oft, when thy luxurious arms have twined
About my jetty neck, have I cried out
Away, those scalding veins burn me it is true.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Devil, it is a lie.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Thou slewest my sweet Maria;
Alvero it was thy daughter, it was: Hortenzo,
She was thy sister; Justice Isabella!
This Serpent poisoned thy dear fathers bed,
Setting large horns on his Imperial head.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Hear me.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha! why?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Madam you shall be heard,
Before the Courts, before the Courts of Spain

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A guard, a guard.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: A guard; for what? for whom?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: To wait on you,
So many great sins must not wait with few.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Keep me in prison! dare you Lords?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: O no!
Were your cause strong, we would not arm you so;
But honour fainting needeth many hands,
Kingdoms stand safe, when mischief lies in bands:
You must to prison.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: Must I? must I, slave!
I will damn thee, ere thou triumphest over my grave.

div.head: Act. V. Scena. III.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: DO, do! my jocund spleen;
It does, it will, it shall, I have at one throw,
Rifled away the Diadem of Spain;
It is gone, and there is no more to set but this
At all, then at this last cast I will sweep up
My former petty losses, or lose all.
Like to a desperate Gamester; ha! how? fast?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Except their bodies turn to airy spirits,
And fly through windows, they are fast my Lord:
If they can eat through locks and bars of Iron,
They may escape, if not? then not.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ho! Zarack!
Wit is a thief, there is pick-lock policy,
To whom all doors fly open: therefore go,
In our name charge the Keeper to resign
His office; and if he have tricks of cruelty,
Let him bequeath them at his death, for kill him;
Turn all thy body into eyes,
And watch them, let those eyes like fiery comets
Sparkle out nothing but the death of Kings.
And. ah! now thus thou knowest I did invent,
A torturing Iron chain.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: O! for necks my Lord.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Aye that, that, that, away and yoke them, stay
Here is Balt. go both, teach them to preach,
Through an Iron Pillory: I will spread a net,
To catch Alvero, o! he is is old and wise,
They are unfit to live, that have sharp eyes, Hortenzo, Roderigo, to it, to it all:
They have supple knees sleeked brows, but hearts of gall:
The bitterness shall be washed off with blood,
Tyrants swim safest in a crimson flood.

sp.speaker: Balt
sp.l: I come to tell your grace that Isabella,
Is with Hortenzo arm in arm at hand,
Zarack and I may kill them, now with ease,
Is it done. and then it is done.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Murther thou the man,
And I will stab her.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: No, I will speed her myself,
Arm in arm, so, so, look upon this Ring,
whoever brings this token to your hands
Regard not for what purpose, seize on them,
And chain them to the rest, they come, away,
Murder be proud, and Tragedy laugh on,
I will seek a stage for thee to jet upon.

div.stage: Enter Isabella, Hortenzo, seeing the Moor turn back.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: My Lord! my Lord Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Hortenzo.
sp.l: Ha! is it you,
Trust me I saw you not.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: What makes your grace so sad?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She grieves for the imprisoned Queen her Mother,
And for Philip, in the sandy heap,
That wait upon an hour, there are not found
So many little bodies as those sighs
And tears, which she hath every Minute spent,
Since her loved Brother felt Imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Pity, great pity, would it lay in me,
To give him liberty.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: It does.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: In me?
Free him, your Mother Queen, and Cardinal too.
In me? alas! not me, no, no, in you;
Yet for I will have my conscience, white and pure,
Here Madam take this Ring, and if my name
Can break down Castle walls, and open Gates,
Take it, and do it, fetch them all forth: and yet,
It is unfit you should go.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That happy office I will execute
Myself.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Will you? would I,
Stood gracious in their sight: well, go,
Do what you will Hortenzo, if this charm
Unbinds them, here it is; Lady, you and I
Aloof will follow him, and when we meet,
Speak for me, for I will kiss Philippo's feet.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: I shall be proud to see all reconciled.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Alas! my Lord, why true, go, go.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Make haste dear love.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hortenzo is a man
Composed of sweet proportion, he has a foot,
A leg, a hand, a face, an eye, a wit,
The best Hortenzo in the Spanish Court.
O! he is the Nonpareil.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Your tongue had wont,
To be more sparing in Hortenzo's praise.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Aye, I may curse his praises, rather ban
Mine own nativity, why did this colour,
Dart in my flesh so far? o! would my face
Were of Hortenzo's fashion, else would your
Were as black as mine is.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Mine like yours, why?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Hark!
I love you, yes faith, I said this, I love you
I do, leave him.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Damnation vanish from me.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.l: Coy? were you as hard as flint O! you should yield
Like softened wax, were you as pure as fire,
I will touch you, yes, I will taint you, see you this,
I will bring you to this lure.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: If I want hands
To kill myself, before thou dost it; do.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I will cut away your hands: well my desire
Is raging as the Sea, and mad as fire,
Will you?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Torment me not good Devil.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: Will you?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: I will tear mine eyes out if they tempt thy lust;

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Touch me not, these knives.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Aye, aye, kill yourself,
Because I jest with you: I wrong Hortenzo?
Settle your thoughts, it was but a trick to try,
That which few women have, true constancy.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: If then my speeches taste of gall.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Nay faith,
You are not bitter, no, you should have railed,
Have spit upon me, spurned me, you are not bitter;
Why do you think that I would nurse a thought,
To hurt your honour? If that thought had brains,
I would beat them out, but come, by this, Hortenzo
Is fast.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Ha! fast?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Aye fast in Philip's arms.
Wrestling together for the price of love;
By this, they are on the way, I will be your guard,
Come follow me, I will lead you in the van,
Where thou shalt see four chins upon one chain.

div.head: Act. V. Scena IV.
div.stage: Enter Hortenzo, Queen Mother, Cardinall, and Philip chaind' by the necks, Zarack, and Baltazar busie about fastning Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: YOu damned Ministers of villainy,
Sworn to damnation by the book of hell;
You maps of night, you element of Devils,
Why do you yoke my neck with Iron chains?

sp.speaker: Baltaz.
sp.l: Many do borrow chains, but you have this
Gratis, for nothing.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Slaves unbind us.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: No --

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I am impatient, veins why crack you not?
And tilt your blood into the face of heaven
To make red clouds like Ensigns in the sky,
Displaying a damned tyrants cruelty;
Yet can I laugh in my extremest pangs,
Of blood, and spirit, to see the Cardinal,
Keep rank with me, and my vile Mother Queen,
To see herself, where she would have me seen.
Good fellowship I'faith.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: And I can tell,
True misery, loves a companion well.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thou leftest me to the mercy of a Moor,
That hath damnation died upon his flesh;
It was well, thou Mother didst unmotherly
Betray thy true son to false bastardy:
Thou leftest me then, now thou art found; and staid,
And thou who didst betray me, art betrayed.
A plague upon you all.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Thou cursest them,
Whom I may curse; first may I curse myself,
Too credulous of Loyalty and love;
Next may I curse the Moor, more than a Devil.
And last thy Mother, mother of all evil.

sp.speaker: Queen Mo.
sp.l: All curses, and all crosses light on thee,
What need I curse myself, when all curse me.
I have been deadly impious I confess,
Forgive me, and my sin will seem the less:
This heavy chain which now my neck assault,
Weighs ten times lighter than my heavy faults.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Hortenzo, I commend myself to thee,
Thou that art nearest, standest furthest off from me.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: That mold of Hell, that Moor has chained me here,
It is not myself, but Isabel I fear.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: It is strange! will not Prince Philip come with Hortenzio.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: He swears he will live and die there.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Marry, and shall;
I pray persuade him you, to leave the place,
A prison? why it is hell; Alas here they be,
Ha! they are they i'faith, see, see, see, see.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Moor, Devil, toad, serpent.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: O sweet airs, sweet voices.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: O my Hortenzo!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Do not these birds sing sweetly Isabella?
O! how their spirits would leap aloft and spring,
Had they their throats at liberty to sing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Damnation dog thee.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Furies follow thee.

sp.speaker: Qu Mo.
sp.l: Comets confound thee.

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: And hell swallow thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Sweeter and sweeter still, O! harmony,
Why there is no music like to misery.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Hast thou betrayed me thus?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Not I, not I.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sirrah, hedge-hog.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha! I will hear thee presently.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Hear me then, Hell-hound; slaves, Unchain my love,
Or by --

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: By what? is it not rare walking here.
Methinks this stage shows like a Tennis Court;
Does it not Isabell? I will show thee how:
Suppose that Iron chain to be the line,
The prison doors the hazard, and their heads
Scarce peeping over the line suppose the balls;
Had I a racket now of burnished steel,
How smoothly could I bandy every ball,
Over this Globe of earth, win set and all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How brisk the villain jets in villainy?

sp.speaker: Eleax.
sp.l: Prating? he is proud because he wears a chain:
Take it off Baltazar, and take him hence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And whither then you dog?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Pity my brother.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Pity him, no; away I come, do, come.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I pray thee kill me: come.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: I hope to see
Thy own hands do that office, down with him.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.l: Is there another hell?

sp.speaker: 2 Moors.
sp.l: Try, try, he is gone.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: So him next, he next, and next him; and then?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Worse than damnation, fiend, monster of men.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Why, when? down, down.

sp.speaker: Card.
sp.l: Slave, as thou thrusts me down,
Into this dungeon, so sink thou to hell.

sp.speaker: Q. Mo.
sp.l: Amen, Amen.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Together so, and you.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: O pity my Hortenzo!

sp.speaker: Horten.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Isabel, my life adieu.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Mischief and horror let the Moor pursue.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A consort, that amain, play that amain.
Amain, Amain. No; so soon fallen asleep,
Nay I will not lose this music, sirrah! sirrah!
Take thou a drum, a Trumpet thou, and Hark;
Mad them with villainous sounds.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: Rare sport, let us go.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: About it. Music will do well, in woe;
How like you this?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: set my Hortenzo free,
And I will like anything.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: A fool, a fool?
Hortenzo free; why look you, he free? no;
Then must he marry you, you must be Queen,
He in a manner King, these dignities
Like poison make men swell, this Ratsbane honour
O it is so sweet, they will lick it till all burst.
He will be proud, and pride you know must fall.
Come, come, he shall not; no, no; it is more meet,
To keep him down, safe standing on his feet.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Eleazar?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Mark: the imperial chair of Spain,
Is now as empty as a Misers Alms;
Be wise, I yet dare fit in it, it is for you,
If you will be for me, there is room for two.
Do meditate, muse on it: it is best for thee
To love me, live with me, and lie with me.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Thou knowest I will first lie in the arms of death,
My meditations are how to revenge,
Thy bloody tyrannies; I fear thee not
Inhumane slave, but to thy face defy
Thy lust, thy love, thy barbarous villainy.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Zarack.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: A-drumming.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: I have made them rave, and curse, and
So; guard her:
Your Court shall be this prison, guard her slaves,
With open eyes; defy me? see my veins,
Strucked out, being over heated with my blood,
Boiling in wrath: I will tame you.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Ha!
I will, and once more fill a kingdoms Throne
Spain I will new-mould thee, I will have a chair
Made all of dead men's bones, and the ascents
Shall be the heads of Spaniards set in ranks;
I will have Philip's head, Hortenzo's head,
Mendoza's head, thy Mothers head, and this,
This head that is so cross, I will have it:
The Scene wants Actors, I will fetch more, and cloth it
In rich Cothurnall pomp. A Tragedy
Ought to be grave, graves this shall beautify.
Moor execute to the life my dread commands,
Vengeance awake, thou hast much work in hand.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: I am weary of this office, and this life,
It is too thirsty, and I would your blood,
Might scape the filling out: By heaven I swear,
I scorn these blows, and his rebukes to bear.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: O! Zarack pity me, I love thee well,
Love deserves pity, pity Isabel.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: What would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: To kill this Moor.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: I will cast an eye of death upon my, face.
I will be no more his slave, swear to advance me;
And by yon setting sun, this hand, and this
Shall rid you of a tyrant.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: By my birth;
No Spaniards honoured place shall equal thine.

sp.speaker: Zarack
sp.l: I will kill him then.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: And Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: And he,

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: I pray thee first, fetch Philippo and Hortenzo
Out of that Hell; they two will be most glad
To aid thee; in this Execution;

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: My Lord Philippo; and Hortenzo; rise;
Your hands; so, talk to her; at my return
This sword shall reek with blood of Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Three curses (like three commendations
To their three souls) I send; thy tortured brother
Does curse the Cardinal, the Moor, thy Mother.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Curse not at all dear souls; revenge is hot,
And boils in Zaracks brains; the plot is cast,
Into the mold of Hell: You freemen are;
Zarack will kill the Moor; and Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: How can that relish?

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.l: Why? I will tell you how?
I did profess; aye, and protested too:
I loved him well, what will not sorrow do?
Then he professed; Aye, and protested too
To kill them both, what will not devils do?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then I profess; aye, and protest it too,
That here is for him, what will not Philip do?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: See where he comes.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: Zarack, what do I see?
Hortenzo and Philip, who did this?

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.l: I Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Balt.
sp.l: Thou art half damned for it, I will to my Lord.

sp.speaker: Zarack.
sp.p: I will stop you on your way, lie there; thy tongue shall tell no tales today

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nor thine tomorrow, his revenge was well.
By this time both the slaves shake hands in hell.

sp.speaker: Isabel.
sp.p: Philippo and Hortenzo stand you still, what; dote you both? cannot you see your play? well fare a woman then, to lead the way. Once rob the dead, put the Moors habits on, and paint your faces with the oil of hell, so waiting on the Tyrant.

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.p: Come no more, it is here, and here; room there below, stand wide, bury them well since they so godly died.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Away then, fate now let revenge be placed.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: And here, a tyrants blood doth sweetly taste.

div.head: Act V. Scena VI.
div.stage: Enter Eleazar, Alvero, Roderigo, Christofero, and other Lords.

sp.speaker: Eleazar.
sp.l: WHat, I imprison, who?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Philip and Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Eleax.
sp.l: Philip and Hortenzo, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Roder
sp.l: Why laughs the Moor?

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.p: I laugh because you jest; laugh at a jest, who I imprison them? I prize their lives with weights, their necks with chains, their hands with Manacles? do I all this, because my face is in nights colour dyed.
Think you my conscience and my soul is so,
Black faces may have hearts as white as snow
And it is a general rule in moral rolls,
The whitest faces have the blackest souls.

sp.speaker: Alvero.
sp.l: But touching my Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: Good old man, I never touched him, do not touch me then with thy Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Christofero.
sp.l: Where is Philip too?

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: And where is Philippo too? I pray I pray, is Philip a tame Spaniard, what can I philip him hither, hither make him fly. First where is Hortenzo, where is Philippo too?

sp.speaker: Roderigo.
sp.l: And where is Isabel, she was with you.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: And where is Isabel, she was with me, and so are you, yet are you well you see but in good time, see where their keepers come. Come hither Zarack, Baltazar, come hither; Zarack, old Lord Alvero asks of thee, where young Hortenzo is.

div.stage: Enter Philip and Hortenzo like Moors.

sp.speaker: Horten
sp.l: My Lord! set free.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.p:
O is he so; come hither Baltazar,
Lord Christofero here would ask of thee where Prince Philippo is.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My Lord set free.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: O is he so! Roderigo asketh me for Isabel,

sp.speaker: Philip
sp.l: I say my Lord she is free.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: O! is she so.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Believe me Lords.

sp.speaker: Hortenzo.
sp.l: And me.

sp.speaker: Philip.
sp.l: I set Philippo.

sp.speaker: Hortenzo.
sp.l: I Hortenzo free.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: My Lords because you shall believe me too,
Go to the Castle, I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Thanks to the mighty Moor, and for his fame,
Be more in honour, than thou art in name;
But let me wish the other prisoners well,
The Queen and Cardinal, let all have right,
Let law absolve them or dissolve them quite.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Grave man, thy gray hairs paint out gravity,
Thy counsel's wisdom, thy wit policy.
There let us meet, and with a general brain,
Erect the peace of spirit and of Spain.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Then will Spain flourish.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Aye, when it is mine.

sp.speaker: Roder.
sp.l: O heavenly meeting!

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: we must part in hell.

sp.speaker: Chri.
sp.l: True peace of joy.

sp.speaker: Ele.
sp.p: It is a dissembling knell. Farewell my Lords, meet there so ha, ha, ha.

Now Tragedy thou Minion of the night, Rhamnusias pew-fellow; to thee I will sing Upon an harp made of dead Spanish bones, The proudest instrument the world affords; When thou in Crimson jollity shalt Bath, Thy limbs as black as mine, in springs of blood; still gushing from the Conduit-head of Spain: To thee that never blushest, though thy cheeks are full of blood. O! Saint revenge to thee: I consecrate my Murders, all my stabs, my bloody labours, tortures, stratagems: The volume of all wounds, that wound from me; mine is the stage, thine is the Tragedy. Where am I now? o at the prison? true, Zarack and Baltazar come hither see, survey my Library. I study, I, whilst you two sleep, marry it is villainy. Here is a good book, Zarack behold it well, it is deeply written for it was made in hell. Now Baltazar, a better book for thee, but for myself, this, this, the best of all; and therefore do I chain it every day, for fear the Readers steal the art away. Where thou standest now, there must Hortenzo hang, Like Tantalus in a maw-eating pang: there
Baltazar must Prince Philip stand, like damned Prometheus, and to act his part; shall have a dagger sticking at his heart. But in my room I will set the Cardinal, and he shall preach Repentance to them all. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Damnation tickles him, he laughs again, Philip must stand there and bleed to death: Well villain I only laugh to see, that we shall live to out-laugh him and thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: O! fit, fit, fit, stay a rare jest, rare jest. Zarack, suppose thou art Hortenzo now? I pray thee stand in passion of a pang, to see by thee how quaintly he would hang.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I am Hortenzo, tut, tut, fear not man, thou lookest like Zarack.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: I Hortenzo, here he shall hang here, I'faith, come Zarack come, and Baltazar take thou Phillipo's room. First let me see you placed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: We are placed.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p:
Slaves, ha, ha, ha, you are but players, they must end the play: how like Hortenzo and Philippo ha, stand my two slaves, were they as black as you. Well Zarack I will unfix thee first of all, thou shalt help me to play the Cardinal; This Iron engine on his head I will clap, like a Pope's Mitre, or a Cardinal's Cap. Then Manacle his hands as thou dost mine: so, so, I pray
thee Zarack set him free, that both of you may stand and laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It is fine I'faith, call in more company,
Alvero, Roderigo, and the rest,
Who will not laugh at Eleazars jest.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: What? Zarack, Baltazar.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Aye, anon, anon, we have not laughed enough, it is but begun.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Unmanacle my hands I say.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then shall we mar our mirth and spoil the play.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Alvero.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let Alvero in.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: And let me out.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I thank you for that flout,
To let Alvero in, and let you out.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: Villains, slaves, am I not your
Lord the Moor, and Eleazar.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: And the Devil of hell,
And more than that, and Eleazar too.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: And Devils dam, what do I here with you.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: My tongue shall torture thee.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: I know thee then, all women's tongues are tortures unto men.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.p:
Spaniards this was the villain, this is he who through enticements of alluring lust, and glory which makes silly women proud, and men malicious, did incense
my spirit beyond the limits of a woman's mind, to wrong myself and that Lord Cardinal; And that which sticks more near unto my blood, he that was nearest to my blood; my son to dispossess him of his right by wrong. O! that I might embrace him on this breast, which did enclose him when he first was born. No greater happiness can heaven shower upon me; than to circle in these arms of mine, that son whose Royal blood I did defame, to Crown with honour an ambitious Moor.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thus then thy happiness is complete:
Behold thy Philip ransomed from that prison
In which the Moor had cloistered him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And here is Hortenzo.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: Then am I betrayed and cozened in my own designs: I did contrive their ruin, but their subtle policy hath blasted my ambitious thoughts: Villains! where is Zarack? where is Baltazar? what have you done with them.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
They are gon to Pluto's kingdom to provide a place for thee, and to attend thee there; but lest they should be tired with too long expecting hopes. Come brave spirits of Spain, this is the Moor the actor of these
evils: Thus thrust him down to act amongst the devils.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.p: And am I thus despatched; had I but breathed the space of one hour longer, I would have fully acted my revenge. But o! now pallid death bids me prepare, and haste to Charon for to be his fare.

I come, I come, but ere my glass is run, I will curse you all, and cursing end my life Mayst thou Lascivious Queen whose damned charms, bewitched me to the circle of thy arms, unpitied die, consumed with loathed lust, which thy venereous mind hath basely nursed. And for you Philip, may your days be long, but clouded with perpetual misery. May thou Hortenzo, and thy Isabell, be fetched alive by Furies into hell, there to be damned for ever, o! I faint; Devils come claim your right, and when I am, confined within your kingdom then shall I, out-act you all in perfect villainy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Take down his body while his blood streams forth, his acts are past, and our last act is done. Now do I challenge my Hereditary right, to the Royal Spanish throne usurped by him. In which, in all your sights I thus do plant myself. Lord Cardinal, and you the Queen my mother, I pardon all those crimes you have committed.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mo.
sp.l: I will now repose myself in peaceful rest,
And fly unto some solitary residence;
Where I will spin out the remnant of my life,
In true contrition for my past offences.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And now Hortenzo to close up your wound,
I here contract my sister unto thee,
With Comic joy to end a tragedy.
And for this Barbarous Moor, and his black train,
Let all the Moors be banished from Spain.

div.trailer: The end of the fifth Act.
